{{distinguish|Carbuncle Cup}} The '''Carbuncle Awards''' are [[architecture]] prizes, given by the Scottish magazine ''[[Urban Realm]]'', formerly ''Prospect'', presented to buildings and areas in Scotland intermittently since 2000.<ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.urbanrealm.com/carbuncles |title=Carbuncles |work=urbanrealm.com |accessdate=2014-09-04}}</ref>
They were established following a discussion about why policy initiatives to improve the quality of the built environment seemed to be having so little impact beyond the centres of Scotland’s key cities.<ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.urbanrealm.com/carbuncles/2005/The_Carbuncle_Awards_2005.html |title=The Carbuncle Awards 2005 |work=urbanrealm.com |accessdate=2014-09-04}}</ref>
The name of the awards is derived from a comment by [[Charles, Prince of Wales|Prince Charles]], an outspoken critic of modern architecture, who in 1984 described [[Ahrends Burton Koralek]]'s proposed extension of London's [[National Gallery]] as a "monstrous [[carbuncle]] on the face of a much-loved and elegant friend".<ref>{{cite web|url=https://www.theguardian.com/artanddesign/2004/may/17/architecture.regeneration|title=Life after carbuncles|first=Jonathan|last=Glancey|date=17 May 2004|publisher=|via=The Guardian}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.princeofwales.gov.uk/speechesandarticles/a_speech_by_hrh_the_prince_of_wales_at_the_150th_anniversary_1876801621.html|title=A speech by HRH The Prince of Wales at the 150th anniversary of the Royal Institute of British Architects (RIBA), Royal Gala Evening at Hampton Court Palace|accessdate=2014-09-04|deadurl=yes|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20070927213205/http://www.princeofwales.gov.uk/speechesandarticles/a_speech_by_hrh_the_prince_of_wales_at_the_150th_anniversary_1876801621.html|archivedate=2007-09-27|df=}}</ref>
There are three award categories: *Plook on the Plinth Award "for the most dismal town in Scotland". A "plook" is a Scottish noun for [[pimple]]. *The Pock Mark Award "for the worst planning decision". *The Zit Building Award "for the worst building completed since the last awards".
Public nominations are made via the magazine's website, with a small group of critics selecting the final winners.
[[Cumbernauld]] in [[Lanarkshire]] has won the Plook on the Plinth Award twice and is the town most frequently nominated for the award.
The Carbuncle Awards inspired the [[Carbuncle Cup]], another [[architecture]] prize launched in 2006 and given annually by ''[[Building Design]]'' magazine to "the ugliest building in the [[United Kingdom]] completed in the last 12 months."<ref name=bd2010>{{cite web |url=http://www.bdonline.co.uk/news/six-in-race-for-carbuncle-cup/5003099.article |title=Six in race for Carbuncle Cup |date=22 July 2010 |author=Watson, Anna |work=bdonline.co.uk |accessdate=2014-09-04}}</ref> The latter has gone on to achieve somewhat greater prominence in the media.

The '''Classic FM Hall of Fame''' is an annual compilation of the most popular 300 [[classical music|classical]] works as polled by listeners of [[Classic FM (UK)|Classic FM]] through a public vote. With more than 150,000 voters, each choosing their three favourites in order of preference, Classic FM claim their Hall of Fame is the world's most comprehensive poll of classical music tastes.<ref>{{cite news|url=http://www.classicfm.co.uk/hall-fame/|title=Classic FM - Hall of Fame}}</ref>
The chart countdown is traditionally broadcast over the Easter weekend, extended by public holidays in the UK, since the event began in 1996.
The compilation is notable for featuring a wide variety of classical works. Pieces by composers such as [[Elgar]] and [[Beethoven]] feature alongside works by contemporary composers such as [[Karl Jenkins]] and [[Ludovico Einaudi]]. Movie soundtracks by [[John Williams]], [[John Barry (composer)|John Barry]] and [[Ennio Morricone]] are also regular features of the chart. And, for the first time in 2012, the chart featured two original works from [[Video game music|video game soundtracks]].
==Current top twenty== The current top twenty was revealed on 2 April 2018.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://halloffame.classicfm.com/2018/|title=Classic FM Hall of Fame|publisher=[[Classic FM (UK)|Classic FM]]|accessdate=2 April 2018}}</ref>
* 1. [[Pyotr Ilyich Tchaikovsky]] – [[1812 Overture]] * 2. [[Sergei Rachmaninoff]] – [[Piano Concerto No. 2 (Rachmaninoff)|Piano Concerto No. 2]] * 3. [[Ralph Vaughan Williams]] – [[The Lark Ascending]] * 4. [[Ralph Vaughan Williams]] – [[Fantasia on a Theme by Thomas Tallis]] * 5. [[Edward Elgar]] – [[Enigma Variations]] * 6. [[Ludwig van Beethoven]] – [[Piano Concerto No. 5 (Beethoven)|Piano Concerto No. 5 ('Emperor')]] * 7. [[Ludwig van Beethoven]] – [[Symphony No. 6 (Beethoven)|Symphony No. 6 ('Pastoral')]] * 8. [[Ludwig van Beethoven]] – [[Symphony No. 9 (Beethoven)|Symphony No. 9 ('Choral')]] * 9. [[Wolfgang Amadeus Mozart]] – [[Clarinet Concerto (Mozart)|Clarinet Concerto]] * 10. [[Gregorio Allegri]] – [[Miserere (Allegri)|Miserere]] * 11. [[Edward Elgar]] – [[Cello Concerto (Elgar)|Cello Concerto]] * 12. [[Jean Sibelius]] – [[Finlandia]] * 13. [[Pyotr Ilyich Tchaikovsky]] – [[The Nutcracker]] * 14. [[Pyotr Ilyich Tchaikovsky]] – [[Swan Lake]] * 15. [[Gustav Holst]] – [[The Planets]] * 16. [[Ludwig van Beethoven]] – [[Symphony No. 7 (Beethoven)|Symphony No. 7]] * 17. [[Johann Pachelbel]] – [[Canon in D]] * 18. [[George Frideric Handel]] – [[Messiah (Handel)|Messiah]] * 19. [[Samuel Barber]] – [[Adagio for Strings]] * 20. [[Karl Jenkins]] – [[The Armed Man|The Armed Man: A Mass for Peace]]
==Previous winners== {|class=wikitable |- !Year!!Winner |- | 1996–2000 | [[Max Bruch]] – [[Violin Concerto No. 1 (Bruch)|Violin Concerto No. 1]] |- | 2001–2005 | [[Sergei Rachmaninoff]] – [[Piano Concerto No. 2 (Rachmaninoff)|Piano Concerto No. 2]] |- | 2006 | [[Wolfgang Amadeus Mozart]] – [[Clarinet Concerto (Mozart)|Clarinet Concerto]] |- | 2007–2010 | [[Ralph Vaughan Williams]] – [[The Lark Ascending]] |- | 2011–2013 | Sergei Rachmaninoff – Piano Concerto No. 2 |- | 2014–2017 | Ralph Vaughan Williams – The Lark Ascending |- | 2018 | [[Pyotr Ilyich Tchaikovsky]] – [[1812 Overture]] |- |} <small>Source</small><ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.classicfm.com/radio/hall-of-fame/ultimate-hall-fame/infographics-statistics-facts/|title=Ultimate Classic FM Hall of Fame: the facts and figures behind the world's biggest classical music poll|publisher=[[Classic FM (UK)|Classic FM]]|accessdate=2 April 2018}}</ref>
==Criticism and controversy== The Hall of Fame has received some criticism due to the lack of variation at the top of the chart.<ref>{{cite news|url=https://www.theguardian.com/tv-and-radio/2012/apr/08/nick-ferrari-classic-fm-interview?newsfeed=true|title=Rewind radio: Classic FM Interview | location=London | work=The Guardian|first=Miranda|last=Sawyer|date=8 April 2012}}</ref> The pieces that make up the top ten have changed very little since the chart began. And, as of 2018, only five different pieces have ever held the number one position.<ref>{{cite news|url=http://news.bbc.co.uk/1/hi/entertainment/312810.stm|title=Bruch and Beatles top radio polls | work=BBC News | date=6 April 1999}}</ref><ref>{{cite news|url=http://news.bbc.co.uk/1/hi/entertainment/4388427.stm|title=Rachmaninov tops classical survey | work=BBC News | date=28 March 2005}}</ref><ref>{{cite news|url=http://news.bbc.co.uk/1/hi/entertainment/4917892.stm|title=Mozart 'UK's favourite composer' | work=BBC News | date=18 April 2006}}</ref><ref>{{cite news|url=http://news.bbc.co.uk/1/hi/entertainment/7311173.stm|title=Vaughan Williams tops radio vote | work=BBC News | date=24 March 2008}}</ref><ref>{{cite news|url=https://www.bbc.co.uk/news/entertainment-arts-43626603|title=1812 Overture is 'top classical piece'|last=Savage|first=Mark|date=3 April 2018|publisher=[[BBC News]]|accessdate=3 April 2018}}</ref>
2013 provided the most controversial Hall of Fame to date due to the prevalence of an organised voting campaign concerning [[video game soundtracks]] by UK based games promoter Mark Robins.<ref>{{cite news|url=http://metro.co.uk/2013/04/02/final-fantasy-and-skyrim-beat-beethoven-in-classic-fm-hall-of-fame-3579567/|title=Final Fantasy and Skyrim beat Beethoven in Classic FM Hall of Fame|date=2 April 2013|work=[[Metro (British newspaper)|Metro]]|accessdate=2 April 2018}}</ref> Several video game soundtracks were voted into the 2013 Hall of Fame, with the highest being [[Nobuo Uematsu]]'s [[Music of the Final Fantasy series|music for ''Final Fantasy'']] at number three.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://halloffame.classicfm.com/2013/chart/position/3/|title=Classic FM Hall of Fame (retrieved 6 April 2013)|work=Classic FM's Hall of Fame|accessdate=October 8, 2014}}</ref>

{{update|date=June 2016}} [[File:Cristina-kirchner-clarin.jpeg|thumb|President [[Cristina Fernández de Kirchner]] with a [[Clarín (Argentine newspaper)|Clarín newspaper]]]]
The Argentine Governments of [[Néstor Kirchner]] and [[Cristina Fernández de Kirchner]] had several conflicts with major media groups. Kirchner accused the [[Grupo Clarín|Clarín Group]], ''[[La Nación]]'', ''[[Perfil]]'', and related media of having promoted their overthrow.
== Background ==
The president and most of her cabinet increasingly avoided [[press conference]]s and [[interview]]s with independent media, relying instead on [[Twitter]], [[press statement]]s, and [[public service announcement]]s to communicate with the populace. Large media groups, particularly the Clarín Group, in turn opposed [[anti-trust law]]s enacted during her administration.<ref name=q>{{cite web|url=http://www.americasquarterly.org/content/media-law-reform-pits-argentine-executive-branch-against-judiciary|title=Media Law Reform Pits Argentine Executive Branch Against Judiciary|work=Americas Quarterly|date=December 7, 2012}}</ref>
Critics maintain that new legislation passed by the Congress would be selectively applied against dissenting media and journalists, while fostering a proliferation of supportive media.<ref name=q/> Supporters maintained in turn that [[media consolidation]] has become the greater threat to freedom of the press in Argentina and elsewhere in Latin America, and that measures such those abolishing media laws dating from the country's [[National Reorganization Process|last dictatorship]] and rescinding criminal penalties for defamation and [[libel]] of the president, promote [[freedom of expression]].<ref name=q/><ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.viomundo.com.br/politica/la-rue-lei-argentina-quebra-um-monopolio-local.html|title=La Rue: Lei argentina quebra um monopólio local|work=Vio Mundo|language=Portuguese|date=December 16, 2012}}</ref>
Other press advocacy groups, such as the Argentine Journalist Forum (FOPEA) and the [[Committee to Protect Journalists]], observed that the dispute polarized news media and public opinion to the point that accuracy and objectivity in the media itself had become jeopardized.<ref name=q/>
==Initial conflicts== {{See also|2008 Argentine government conflict with the agricultural sector}} The conflict started in 2008, during a period in which the government was in open confrontation with the [[Agriculture of Argentina|agricultural sector]] over a propose hike in [[oilseed]] export taxes. The [[Grupo Clarín|Clarín Group]], led by CEO [[Héctor Magnetto]], strongly supported the sector,<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.perfil.com/contenidos/2010/08/12/noticia_0013.html|title=Magnetto: 'Nosotros nos pusimos al frente del conflicto y a partir de allí, el Gobierno decidió destruirnos.'|work=Perfil|date=12 August 2008}}</ref> and their newspapers published articles that were considered favorable to the "ruralists" or ''chacareros''.<ref>Petras and Veltmeyer (2009), p. 90.</ref> At least one writer who worked for one of the conglomerate's dailies (Enrique Lacolla of ''[[La Voz del Interior]]'') was dismissed for submitting an [[op ed]] opposing the landowners' [[Lockout (industry)|lockout]] of April 2008.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.prensared.com.ar/indexmain.php?lnk=1&mnu=10&idnota=4527|title=Intolerancia y doble discurso|work=Círculo Sindical de la Prensa y la Comunicación de Córdoba|publisher=''Crítica de la Argentina''|date=April 14, 2008}}</ref>
The president reacted with strong criticism of the role of media, questioning whether freedom of speech "belonged to corporations or to ordinary citizens." The Government sent its "Resolution 125" to Congress, which after an 18-hour Senate debate, fell in a tie vote broken by the Vice President [[Julio Cobos]] in a surprise vote against the [[Government of Argentina#Executive branch|executive branch]] resolution.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.lanacion.com.ar/nota.asp?nota_id=1030952|title=Tras una dramática sesión, el vicepresidente Cobos desempató la votación al rechazar el proyecto oficial de retenciones|work=La Nación|date=17 June 2008}}</ref>
Another source of contention with the government arose when the Clarín Group was denied regulatory support for the planned acquisition in 2008 of a controlling stake in [[Telecom Argentina]], which would have given the media group a [[Triple play (telecommunications)|dominant position]] in domestic [[Communications of Argentina|internet, television, and phone services]].<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.tradingmarkets.com/news/stock-alert/grcnl_-argentina-ex-president-clarin-offered-spin-for-telephone-co-725534.html|title=Argentina Ex-President: Clarín Offered Spin For Telephone Co|work=Trading Markets}}{{dead link|date=August 2017 |bot=InternetArchiveBot |fix-attempted=yes }}</ref> ''La Nación'' was likewise at odds with the federal government over an [[injunction]] issued in October 2003 that allowed it to continue in subsequent years to claim an expired corporate tax credit on payroll taxes paid; were the injunction to be lifted, a 280 million-peso ([[United States dollar|US$]]50 million) tax debt, including interest, would result.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.agepeba.org/lectura.asp?id=2821|title=El diario La Nación, la cautelar más larga y una deuda de 280 millones|work=Agencia Periodística de Buenos Aires|date=January 6, 2013}}</ref>
==Nationalization of football broadcasting==
The television broadcasting rights for all [[Football in Argentina|Argentine football]]{{#tag:ref|[[Association football|Football]] or ''fútbol'' (Spanish), is what in the United States is commonly known as soccer.|group=N}} league matches had been held by the Clarín Group cable channel [[TyC Sports]] since 1992. That contract was terminated by the [[Argentine Football Association]] in August 2009, and broadcasts of all league matches were made freely available as ''Fútbol para Todos'' ("Football for All"). These broadcasts were afterwards used to provide advertising for the government, and with the single exception of [[Iveco]] no advertisements from nongovernmental sources were aired after March 2010.<ref>{{cite web |url= http://www.losandes.com.ar/notas/2010/3/28/economia-480705.asp|title= El "Fútbol para todos" ya no acepta publicidad de anunciantes privados|trans-title="Soccer for all" no longer takes advertising from commercial sources|language= Spanish|author= Martín Bidegaray|date= March 28, 2010|work= Los Andes}}</ref>
==Audiovisual Media Law== In October 2009, the [[Argentine National Congress]] approved Law 26.522, known as the "Audiovisual Media Law"<ref>[http://www.leydemedios.com.ar/ "Ley de Medios."] {{webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20100827120944/http://www.leydemedios.com.ar/ |date=2010-08-27 }} {{es icon}} ''leydemedios.com.'' Retrieved: 1 September 2010.</ref> but usually described as the "K Law" by the Clarín Group.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.tn.com.ar/politica/44464/ley-k-apuran-el-dictamen|title=Ley 'K': apuran el dictamen|work=TN Noticias|date=1 September 2010}}</ref> The new law served to [[deregulation|deregulate]] the television and radio industries which until then were still limited to the few channels created by the media law enacted in 1980.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.minutouno.com.ar/minutouno/nota/134581|title=Reglamentan la ley de medios audiovisuales: El Gobierno publicó la nueva norma en el Boletín Oficial a pesar de los amparos presentados|work=Minuto Uno|date=1 September 2010}}</ref> A series of five judicial appeals and [[injunction]]s prevented it from coming into force for almost a year. The Supreme Court ruled against one of those appeals,<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.lanacion.com.ar/nota.asp?nota_id=1275277|title=La Corte rechazó un planteo contra la ley de medios y marcó límites a los jueces|work=La Nación Política|date=15 June 2010}}</ref> declaring that it created a precedent where "a single legislator could not challenge an act of Congress,{{#tag:ref|The single legislator who acted in this case, was Enrique Thomas ([[Federal Peronism]], [[Mendoza Province]]).|group=N}} nor judges use their authority to stop the application of an entire law."<ref name="cuatro"/> The [[Antitrust law|antitrust]] provisions of the law remained blocked subsequently via injunctions.<ref name="cuatro">{{cite web|url=http://www.lanacion.com.ar/1300223|title=El Gobierno pretende hacer entrar en vigor la ley de medios pese a los frenos impuestos por la Justicia|work=La Nación|date=15 June 2010}}</ref>
A court ruling in December 2012 ruled that the Clarín Group’s television and radio licenses cannot be sold until the [[Supreme Court of Argentina|Argentine Supreme Court]] can rule on the constitutionality of articles 45 and 161, which limit the amount of licenses companies can hold and which establish a divestment procedure for companies who hold more than 24 cable television licenses and 10 [[free-to-air]] radio or television licenses. The Argentine government claims the Clarín Group has over 200 licenses; Grupo Clarín claims the number is 158.<ref name=q/> The Supreme Court ultimately upheld the constitutionality of the Audiovisual Media Law in its entirety on October 29, 2013.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.telam.com.ar/english/notas/201310/852-the-supreme-court-declares-the-constitutionality-of-the-media-law.html|title=The Supreme Court declares the constitutionality of the Media Law|work=Télam|date=October 29, 2013}}</ref>
[[Frank LaRue]], the [[UN Special Rapporteur]] on Freedom of Expression, supports the new law, which replaces the law enacted in 1980 under the [[National Reorganization Process]] dictatorship, as "an example for the entire continent." A majority of journalist respondents in a 2011 Argentine Journalism Forum (FOPEA) survey considered the new law a partial or even substantial progress compared to the previous one.<ref name=q/>
==Marcela and Felipe Noble Herrera== {{main article|Noble brothers case}} Marcela and Felipe Noble Herrera are adopted children of [[Ernestina Herrera de Noble]], the largest shareholder of the Clarín Group. It was suspected that they may be children of [[Forced disappearance|people murdered]] during the [[Dirty War]]. The President pledged to "personally" go to international courts to seek justice done if Argentine judges did not rule on the case.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.buenosairesherald.com/BreakingNews/View/30210|title=Court rules in favour of Grandmothers|work=Buenos Aires Herald|date=31 August 2010}}</ref>
Charges of illicit adoption were not ultimately proven by DNA tests against the available pool of data, and the [[Grandmothers of the Plaza de Mayo]] NGO, who advocated for these tests, celebrated that the case was at least taken up in court.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.lanacion.com.ar/1435763-carlotto-el-caso-noble-quedo-resuelto-por-ley|title=Carlotto: el caso Noble 'quedó resuelto por ley'|work=La Nación|date=27 December 2011}}</ref> [[Estela Barnes de Carlotto]] also considered that the case will remain open, as further tests will be done as new families submit blood samples.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.rosario3.com/noticias/noticias.aspx?idNot=121361|title=Carlotto en Rosario: 'El caso Noble no está cerrado'|work=Rosario 3}}</ref> The Noble Herrera lawyers motioned instead that the case against Ernestina Herrera de Noble be closed, as happened with all the similar cases when the DNA tests gave negative results.<ref>{{cite web |url= http://www.clarin.com/politica/Caso-Noble-Herrera-ADN-negativo_0_605339518.html|title= Caso Noble Herrera: tres nuevos análisis de ADN dieron negativo|trans-title=Noble Herrera case: three new DNA tests were negative|language= Spanish|date= December 8, 2011|work=Clarín}}</ref> The case was finally closed in January 2016.<ref>[http://www.lanacion.com.ar/1859283-la-jueza-sandra-arroyo-salgado-sobreseyo-a-ernestina-herrera-de-noble-en-la-causa-por-apropiacion-de-ninos-durante-la-dictadura La jueza Sandra Arroyo Salgado sobreseyó a Ernestina Herrera de Noble en la causa por apropiación de niños durante la dictadura] {{es}}</ref>
==Cablevisión== [[Cable television]] reaches two out of three Argentine households,<ref>{{cite web|url=http://seniales.blogspot.com/2012/03/85-millones-de-hogares-argentinos.html|title=8,5 millones de hogares argentinos conectados al cable|work=Señales}}</ref> and is at the center of debate over the 2009 Audiovisual Media Law. The Clarín Group's cable TV unit, ''Cablevisión'', merged with rival ''Multicanal'' in 2007 and since then controls the majority of the cable market in Argentina, including a 90% share of cable households in Buenos Aires, Córdoba, and Santa Fe Provinces (the three largest); potential competitors have likewise been stifled by [[predatory pricing]] and by Cablevisión's control of 97% of the [[fiber optic cable]] mileage in Argentina.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.infonews.com/2012/08/23/economia-35420-como-se-termina-con-el-monopolio-de-cablevision.php|title=¿Cómo se termina con el monopolio de Cablevisión?|work=InfoNews|date=August 23, 2012}}</ref>
Besides the Media Law, the federal government has used its regulatory power over rates against Cablevisión; when Cablevisión and [[DirecTV]] intended to increase subscriber rates in March 2010, the Argentine government appealed. Subsequently, in August 2010, a Federal Judge {{#tag:ref|The federal court involved was Cámara de Apelaciones in the ''Contencioso Administrativo, Nº 3.''|group=N}} supported the government decision and prevented the two companies from changing their basic rates.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.minutouno.com.ar/minutouno/nota/134554-La-Justicia-falla-contra-CableVision-por-suba-del-abono-a-los-clientes/|title=La Justicia falla contra CableVisión por suba del abono a los clientes|work=Minuto Uno|date=31 August 2010}}</ref> Cablevisión later disregarded a February 2011 order by the Federal Audioviual Services Authority that the [[INCAA]], [[CN23]], and [[TeleSUR]] networks be included in its lineup; children's programming channel [[Pakapaka]] was likewise excluded, but was added in May as part of the "premium plan."<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.pagina12.com.ar/diario/ultimas/20-161563-2011-02-01.html|title=Mariotto: Quien no cumpla la ley será sancionado|work=Página/12|date=February 1, 2011}}</ref> A court ruling in June 2013 enjoined Cablevisión to reorganize its channel lineup and to include the hitherto excluded channels.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.diariosobrediarios.com.ar/dsd/notas/5/483-remarcaron-que-cablevision-tendra-que-ordenar-su-grilla-e-incluir-canales.php#.UedZwm21tRw|title=Remarcaron que Cablevisión tendrá que ordenar su grilla e incluir canales|work=Diario sobre Diarios|date=June 7, 2013}}</ref>
==Papel Prensa== [[Papel Prensa]] is the largest Argentine producer of [[newsprint]].<ref name=cifras>{{cite web|url=http://sur.infonews.com/notas/un-repaso-por-las-cifras-del-mercado-de-papel-de-diariohttp://www.pagina12.com.ar/diario/economia/2-185676-2012-01-18.html|title=Un repaso por las cifras del mercado de papel de diario|work=Miradas Al Sur|date=January 22, 2012}}</ref> The company is owned by the newspapers ''[[Clarín (Argentine newspaper)|Clarín]]'' and ''[[La Nación]]'', with a 27.5% share owned by the Argentine government.<ref>[http://www.papelprensa.com/PP-01.html "Papel Prensa"]</ref> President Cristina Fernández de Kirchner alleged that the sale of Papel Prensa by the family of the late [[David Graiver]] in 1976 was done so by illicit means and in collusion with the dictatorship to take advantage of its use against other Argentine newspapers, as well as toeing the dictatorship line when covering the Dirty War in which up to 30,000 people were forcibly disappeared. The government presented a report, ''Papel Prensa: The Truth'', claiming that during the [[Dirty War]], while being coerced, the Graivers were forced to sell Papel Prensa at a bargain price.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.elargentino.com/nota-103985-Papel-Prensa-el-Gobierno-denunciara-a-Clarin-y-La-Nacion.html|title=Papel Prensa: el Gobierno denunciará a Clarín y La Nación|work=El Argentino|date=30 August 2010}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.lanacion.com.ar/1297608|title=Cristina Kirchner atacó a Papel Prensa y acudirá a la Justicia para que investigue la operación de compra|work=La Nación|date=24 August 2010}}</ref>
Shortly afterward Isidoro Graiver denied the charges, stating that the sale of the company took place while his brothers were free, and that their detention was not related to [[Papel Prensa]] but with their link to the ''[[Montoneros]]'' guerrilla group.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.lanacion.com.ar/1297876|title=Isidoro Graiver refuta a la Presidenta|work=La Nación|date=25 August 2010}}</ref> He had made statements to the contrary one month earlier,<ref>{{cite web|url=http://tiempo.infonews.com/notas/entrevista-isidoro-graiver|title=Entrevista a Isidoro Graiver|work=InfoNews|date=August 26, 2010}}</ref> and was therefore later accused of being manipulated by ''Clarín''.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://tiempo.elargentino.com/notas/se-demostro-que-fue-pagado|title=Se demostró que fue pagado|work=Tiempo Argentino|date=25 August 2010}}</ref>
The ''Nunca Más'' report, published in 1984 by the [[National Commission on the Disappearance of Persons]], contains no information about the Graivers being forced to give away their property.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.lanacion.com.ar/1297858|title=Sin rastros del caso en el "Nunca Más."|work=La Nación|date=25 August 2010}}</ref> Michael Soltys, editor of the ''[[Buenos Aires Herald]]'' newspaper declared: "Papel Prensa is an anachronistic holdover from the military dictatorship which should not continue any further into the 21st century; but not this way. It is not only that the government is at least as interested a party when it comes to controlling newsprint — if this control is established on such a mendacious basis, the Cristina Fernández de Kirchner administration is not so much seeking the truth as to be the owner of the truth."<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.buenosairesherald.com/BreakingNews/View/43197|title=Super Tuesday?|work=Buenos Aires Herald|date=1 September 2010}}</ref> On same day of its announcement, the government sent the report to the National Congress and the Judiciary for further investigation.
Another source of contention between the government and its private partners in Papel Prensa is that production at the firm's [[San Pedro, Buenos Aires|San Pedro]] facility has been well below capacity and declining, leading to increasing imports of a staple considered one of national interest.<ref name=cifras/> A preferential pricing scale that allowed ''La Nación'' and the Clarín Group's numerous dailies to buy newsprint at a 25% discount while other dailies were charged prices based on expensive Chilean imports, was rescinded in 2010.<ref name=cifras/>
On April 2013 Congressman [[Carlos Kunkel]] presented a bill to expropriate the 24% of Papel Prensa, thereby raising the state's share to 51% and thus putting the newsprint maker under state control; the bill would dismiss all current board members and executives in Papel Prensa, and appoint new ones.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.lanacion.com.ar/1580641-el-oficialismo-impulsa-una-expropiacion-para-controlar-papel-prensa|title=El oficialismo impulsa una expropiación para controlar Papel Prensa|work=La Nación}}</ref>
==Fibertel== [[Fibertel]], a [[Broadband Internet access]] provider and part of the Clarín Group,{{#tag:ref|''Fibertel'' was an independent company 1997–2003 before its acquisition by the Clarín Group in 2003.|group=N}} had its licence revoked in August 2010 by the government arguing that Clarín itself dissolved Fibertel in January 2009, merging the company with its TV cable network provider Cablevisión, and does not have a licence to provide Internet services by itself.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://tiempo.elargentino.com/notas/se-quejan-porque-que-gobierno-hizo-caducar-licencia-de-fibertel-que-dejo-de-existir-2009|title=Se quejan porque que el gobierno hizo caducar la licencia de Fibertel, que dejó de existir en 2009|work=Tiempo Argentino|date=August 21, 2010}}</ref> The government gave a 90-day time limit to end operations and move current users to other providers. The case was taken to the courts to prevent ''Fibertel''{{'}}s closure, which would force 10% of the country's Internet users {{#tag:ref|''Fibertel'' is the third-largest [[Internet service provider|ISP]] in Argentina with approximately 1,500,000 clients in 2012.|group=N}} to change to a new service provider or get disconnected.<ref>[https://www.cia.gov/library/publications/the-world-factbook/geos/ar.html "Argentina."] ''cia.gov.'' Retrieved: 30 August 2010.</ref>
More controversy arose in September 2010 when the Government's Secretary of Communications office published a list of 389 Internet providers that could potentially replace Fibertel. The list, however, was totally outdated and resulted in only 22 companies still operating and only two ''Telcos'' with nationwide coverage: ''[[Telefónica#Argentina|Telefónica de Argentina]]'' and ''[[Telecom Argentina]]''.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.lanacion.com.ar/nota.asp?nota_id=1298559|title=No da Internet la mayoría de las alternativas oficiales a Fibertel|work=La Nación|date=7 September 2010}}</ref>
Judge Ernesto Marinelli of the First National Court on Federal Administration Contentions was initially chosen to preside over the case, but declared himself in a "conflict of interest" because he was a Fibertel user.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.abogados.com.ar/un-juez-se-excuso-en-el-caso-fibertel-por-ser-abonado-a-la-empresa/6375|title=Un Juez Se Excusó en el Caso Fibertel Por Ser Abonado a la Empresa|work=Abogados|date=26 August 2010}}</ref> At the same time, the different factions in the National Congress were divided on the issue. [[Pino Solanas]] of the [[Proyecto Sur]] Party, for example, proposed that the country should have a new law to deregulate and promote all the communication services instead of regulating a single company.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.pagina12.com.ar/diario/elpais/1-152731-2010-09-07.html|title=La oposición, separada por una red|work=Página/12|date=7 September 2010}}</ref>
==International notice== The disputes over ''Fibertel'' and ''Papel Prensa'' took place nearly at the same time, and generated strong reaction from the international media. ''El País'' from Uruguay highlighted the confrontation between government and the ''Grupo Clarín'' media concern.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.elpais.com.uy/10/08/24/pinter_510570.asp|title=Medios denuncian embestida del gobierno 'k' y falta de libertades|work=El País|date=August 24, 2010}}</ref>
Criticism of the Argentine government included an editorial by [[Mary Anastasia O'Grady]] from ''[[The Wall Street Journal]]'' who said that Kirchnerism is "cracking down on the free press."<ref>{{cite web|url=https://www.wsj.com/articles/SB10001424052748703573604574493541233653908|title=Argentina's Kirchner Targets the Press|work=The Wall Street Journal|date=26 October 2009}}</ref> Editorial comment from Spain's ''[[El País]]'' was of the opinion that Kirchnerism is "using methods similar to those of dictatorships to keep its power" by revisiting the ''Papel Prensa'' case.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.elpais.com/articulo/opinion/Callar/voces/criticas/elpepiopi/20100827elpepiopi_3/Tes|title=Callar las voces críticas: La nueva campaña de Kirchner contra la prensa independiente prueba su veta más autoritaria|work=El País|date=27 August 2010}}</ref>
Other voices echoed a different view, including editorial comments in ''[[El Tiempo (Colombia)|El Tiempo]]'' from Colombia, declaring: "The government maintains that the company sells the paper to small newspapers at higher prices than those who buy ''Clarín'' and ''La Nación'' and considered these actions go against freedom of expression."<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.eltiempo.com/mundo/latinoamerica/gobierno-argentino-presento-proyecto-para-reducir-poder-de-medios-sobre-papel_7882931-2|title=Presidenta argentina presenta proyecto ante Congreso para reducir poder de periódicos sobre el papel|work=El Tiempo}}</ref> UN Special Rapporteur on Freedom of Expression [[Frank LaRue]] also supports the new law;<ref name=q/> as does the world's largest federation of journalists, the [[International Federation of Journalists]], whose director, Beth Costa, visited [[Martín Sabbatella]] of the AFSCA (the agency overseeing the Audiovisual Media Law) in August 2013 to express the IFJ's "support for and commitment to the media law and the defense of freedom of expression in Argentina."<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.infonews.com/2013/08/31/politica-95193-fuerte-apoyo-de-la-federacion-internacional-de-periodistas-a-la-ley-de-medios-ley-de-medios.php|title=Fuerte apoyo de la Federación Internacional de Periodistas a la Ley de Medios|work=InfoNews|date=August 31, 2013}}</ref>
In August 2010, [[U.S. Department of State]] Deputy Spokesman Mark Toner declared that the [[Barack Obama administration]] is closely following the controversy and that concerns about press freedom are taken seriously.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://en.mercopress.com/2010/08/26/us-closely-following-argentine-debate-on-freedom-of-the-press|title=US closely following Argentine debate on freedom of the press|work=Merco Press|date=26 August 2010}}</ref> [[File:Jorge Capitanich 2015-02-02.jpg|thumb|[[Jorge Capitanich]] destroying a [[Clarín (Argentine newspaper)|Clarín newspaper]] after accusing the newspaper of publishing false information.]]
==Pro-government media and state advertising==
The government has made increasing use of advertising during the Kirchner era. State publicity - at all levels of government - accounted for 1.8% of Argentina's 3 billion-peso (US$1 billion) ad market in 2003, but fully 8% of a 19.5 billion-peso (US$4.7 billion) ad market in 2011 - an almost twentyone-fold increase.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.chequeado.com/ultimas-noticias/1370-scoccimarro-la-pauta-oficial-representa-solo-el-5-del-total-en-relacion-a-la-privada.html|title=Scoccimarro: La pauta oficial representa sólo el 5% del total en relación a la privada|work=Chequeado.com|date=November 27, 2012}}</ref> The official budget for national government publicity in 2012 was 735.8 million pesos (US$160 million); the 2011 budget was $608.1 million (US$146 million). An administrative resolution increased that number by $4.7 million, a presidential decree added $112.8 million, and another administrative resolution allowed to use $10.2 million more.<ref name="doslucasaldia">{{cite web|url=http://www.clarin.com/politica/Relato-gastan-millones-difundir-gobierno_0_625137508.html|title=Relato K: ya se gastan 2 millones por día para difundir actos de gobierno|work=Clarín}}</ref> A General Audit Office (AGN) report showed that in 2009, the largely supportive ''[[Página 12]]'' daily and [[Veintitrés]] Group received 18% and 13% of these revenues, respectively; while ''Clarín'', ''La Nación'', and ''[[La Razón (Buenos Aires)|La Razón]]'' received 15%, 8%, and 5% despite their much larger circulation.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://ar.noticias.yahoo.com/agn-denunci%C3%B3-uso-publicidad-oficial-000000396.html|title=La AGN denunció el uso de la publicidad oficial|work=Yahoo! Noticias Argentina|date=February 6, 2013}}</ref>
Advertising is not the sole venue used by the government to broadcast publicity. The nationalized soccer broadcasts, whose commercial breaks feature mostly state ads, are officially budgeted at $690 million (US$150 million). A presidential decree allocated another $38.5 million, that with a loan of $25 million to the [[Argentine Football Association]] totals $753.5 million (US$165 million). The Ministry of Economy has a special budget for this purpose of $42.8 million.<ref name="doslucasaldia"/> Nor is criticism of excessive ad spending limited to the federal government; a leading opponent, Buenos Aires Mayor [[Mauricio Macri]], had the city spend over $86 million (US$20 million) in publicity during the first quarter of 2012 alone, dwarfing the 8 million pesos spent on city health and education infranstructure combined.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.bouex.com/news/max/1255_Macri-pone-86-para-publicidad2c-3-para-escuelas-y-4-en-salud.htm|title=Macri pone 86 para publicidad, 3 para escuelas y 4 en salud|work=Bouex|date=July 27, 2012}}</ref>

{{About||the psychological condition|Coulrophobia}} {{multipleissues| {{missing information|the film's production|date=May 2017}} {{lead too short|date=August 2015}} }} {{Infobox film | name = Fear of Clowns | image = fear-of-clowns.jpg | image_size = | border = | alt = | caption = Film poster | film name = | director = [[Kevin Kangas]] | producer = Rick Ganz
Kevin Kangas | writer = Kevin Kangas | screenplay = | story = | based on = | narrator = | starring = Rick Ganz
Mark Lassise
Jacqueline Reres | music = Chad Seiter | cinematography = David Mun | editing = Harvey Glatman | studio = Kangas Kahn Films
Marauder Productions | distributor = SNP | released = {{Film date|2004|10|28|[[Baltimore]], [[Maryland]]}} | runtime = 120 minutes | country = United States | language = English | budget = | gross = }} '''''Fear of Clowns''''' is a 2004 [[horror film]] written and directed by [[Kevin Kangas]]. It was followed by a 2007 sequel entitled ''[[Fear of Clowns 2]]''. == Plot == Lynn Blodgett, an artist with [[coulrophobia]], has a nightmare in which she is a young girl and encounters a clown with a decomposing face after a car crash at a [[carnival]]. Lynn's nightmares have been getting worse since she filed for divorce from her husband, Doctor Bert Tokyo, who hit her upon getting the news, and is fighting for full custody of their son, Nicholas. One night, a shirtless clown ("Shivers") with black eyes and a [[battle axe]] gazes at Lynn's house, then walks away. In the morning, Lynn is told that a family living near where she was [[house sitting]] was massacred. At a gallery exhibiting her work, most of which involves monstrous clowns, Lynn meets Tucker Reid, a roller coaster tycoon who purchases one of her paintings for $8000. Tuck invites Lynn to his office, and after the tour, the two are attacked by a mugger, Heston, but escape. Lynn is shaken by the attempted robbery, but brushes off Tuck's offer to stay at her house. Lynn answers a call from the gallery owner and faints after spotting Shivers standing on her patio. The gallery owner then calls the police, who later question Lynn and dismiss her story. At the gallery, Lynn reluctantly accepts an offer of $20,000 to do a portrait of a man's father, a clown and convicted child molester. Elsewhere, Shivers is tormented by voices, which tell him that he will get better if he continues to terrorize Lynn. Lynn meets with Bert and his lawyer, who state that Bert not only wants custody of Nicholas, but also wants child support, and half the rights and profits to all the paintings that Lynn has created and sold since they married. It is also revealed that Bert has been out of work for six months, and has been lying about being preoccupied with his job. Shivers stalks Lynn as she is walking with Tuck, and later murders Lynn's friend Amanda. Lynn is contacted by Detective Peters, who tells her about Amanda's death, and that he now believes her story about being scared by a clown, as grease paint was found under Amanda's nails, and in a colorful pattern on one of her windows. In a parking lot, Bert meets with Heston, who he has hired to kill Lynn so he can collect [[life insurance]]. Heston successfully badgers Bert into giving him more money, due to the complications caused by Shivers and the police. Bert visits Shivers, who is revealed to be Doug Richardson, a former patient of his, a sex offender with [[Leber's congenital amaurosis]]. Worried that Shivers will wreck his plans, Bert orders him to leave Lynn alone. Ignoring Bert, Shivers sends a party clown to Lynn's house to distract the guard, who he beheads, spotting Heston nearby as he does so. When Shivers leaves, Heston breaks into Lynn's home, and is shot with his own gun during a struggle with Lynn and Tuck, who had stopped by to check on Lynn. At the Tokyo residence, Shivers murders Bert, due to Bert trying to have Heston assassinate Lynn, and thus almost ruining Shivers's chance to be "cured". While the authorities are content with believing that Heston was Shivers, Lynn is unconvinced. Nevertheless, she decides to go out on a date to a theatre with Tuck to celebrate being paid $100,000 for the painting she was hired to do. Shivers continues his mission of trying to rid himself of his [[schizophrenia]] through Lynn. He kills her boss, abducts Nicholas after dismembering his babysitter, and breaks into the theatre, where he butchers two employees. As Shivers pursues Lynn and Tuck, Detective Peters races to the theatre, having gotten an alert about a 911 call from it, and news that the DNA under Amanda's fingernails matches Doug. Shivers uses Nicholas to lure Lynn out, and as the clown is about to kill her, Tuck blinds him from a [[projectionist]] booth, incapacitating him long enough for Peters and other officers to arrive, and arrest him. Lynn goes home, and has a nightmare about Shivers escaping from prison, and attacking her and Nicholas. == Cast == * Rick Ganz as Tucker Reid * Jacqueline Reres as Lynn Blodgett * Mark Lassise as Doug Richardson/Shivers the Clown * Carl Randolph as Doctor Bert Tokyo * Frank Lama as Detective Peters * Ted Taylor as Heston * John Patrick Barry as Officer Patrick * Andrew Schneider as Phillip * Lauren Pellegrino as Amanda Green * Lisa Willis Brush as Julie * Christopher Lee Philips as Osbourne * Judith Furlow as Gale Wroten * Patrick T. McGowan as Endle Parrish * Jack-Joseph Porter as Nicholas Blodgett * Darla Albornoz as Mediator * Steven Gleich as Marty * Jed Duvall as Happy Clown * Rich Herard as Black Cop * Ronald Lee Ward, Jr. as Paramedic * Rich Henn as Cop #3 * James Fellows as Bobby * Jeff Volpe as Jeff * Bill Stull as Veteran Cop * Jeremy Cavey as Young Cop * Samantha Koehler as Young Lynn Blodgett * Steve Carson as Cop with Children * [[Kevin Kangas]] as Cop Who Ate Too Many Doughnuts ==Production== {{expand section|date=September 2014}} ==Release== {{expand section|date=September 2014}} The film made its [[DVD]] debut on Feb 28, 2006 where it was released by Live/Artisan.{{cite web|title=Fear of Clowns (2004) - Kevin Kangas|url=http://www.allmovie.com/movie/fear-of-clowns-v340317/releases|website=Allmovie.com|publisher=AllMovie|accessdate=17 August 2015}} == Reception == Critical reception for the film has been mixed to negative. [[Dread Central]] gave ''Fear of Clowns'' a 2½ out 5, and said that while the villain was intimidating and the film had "a few ambitious twists and turns" it was marred by uneven and inconsistent writing, and poor direction, though the website ultimately admitted that "For horror fans, ''Fear of Clowns'' is definitely worth a look. The film hits its mark much more than it misses and all in all is a fun ride".{{cite web|url = http://www.dreadcentral.com/reviews/fear-clowns-dvd|title = ''Fear of Clowns'' (DVD)|last = Barton|first = Steve|publisher = [[Dread Central]]|date = 1 March 2006|website = dreadcentral.com|accessdate = 6 July 2013}} A 2/5 was awarded by [[DVD Talk]], which wrote, "Although it has a few tense moments and creatively creepy scenes, ''Fear of Clowns'' runs on way too long" and "There's some good stuff tucked away in the generally forgettable ''Fear of Clowns'' -- and I'll gladly admit that it's a marked improvement over ''[[Hunting Humans]]'' -- but it's just too dry and familiar a tale".{{cite web|url = http://www.dvdtalk.com/reviews/20456/fear-of-clowns/|title = ''Fear of Clowns''|last = Weinberg|first = Scott|publisher = [[DVD Talk]]|date = 3 March 2006|website = dvdtalk.com|accessdate = 6 July 2013}} The same grade was given by [[Bloody Disgusting]], which wrote that the film was unfocused and overlong, and the characters largely two-dimensional, despite the solid performances of Jacky Reres and Mark Lassise as Lynn and Shivers, respectively.{{cite web|url = http://bloody-disgusting.com/reviews/109109/fear-of-clowns-v-2/|title = ''Fear of Clowns'' (V)|last = |first = |publisher = [[Bloody Disgusting]]|date = 7 March 2006|website = bloody-disgusting.com|accessdate = 21 September 2014}} [[JoBlo.com|Arrow in the Head]]'s Andre Manseau bestowed a score of 3½ out of 5, and summed up his feelings towards ''Fear of Clowns'' by calling it "a decent low budget [[Slasher film|slasher]]".{{cite web|url = http://www.joblo.com/horror-movies/dvd-reviews/fear-of-clowns|title = ''Fear of Clowns''|last = Manseau|first = Andre|publisher = Arrow in the Head|date = |website = joblo.com|accessdate = 21 September 2014}} [[Ain't It Cool News]] responded well to ''Fear of Clowns'' and its sequel, concluding, "If you're patient enough to sit through some lulls and low fi rough edges, [[Kevin Kangas|Kangas]] delivers some definite shivers with his ''Fear of Clowns'' series".{{cite web|url = http://www.aintitcool.com/node/67916|title = AICN HORROR Send in the Clowns: Bug confronts the indie horrors of ''Fear of Clowns'' & ''Fear of Clowns 2''!|last = Bug|first = Ambush|publisher = [[Ain't It Cool News]]|date = 8 July 2014|website = aintitcool.com|accessdate = 26 September 2014}} == References == {{Reflist}} == External links == * {{Official website|http://kangaskahnfilms.com}} * {{IMDb title|0362636|Fear of Clowns}} * {{Rotten tomatoes|fear_of_clowns|Fear of Clowns}} * [http://www.iconsoffright.com/IV_Kangas.htm Interview with Kevin Kangas] at Icons of Fright.com * {{Allmovie|340317|Fear of Clowns}} [[Category:2004 films]] {{Infobox Musical |name= From A to Z |subtitle= |image= FromA2Z.jpg |caption= Program, Shubert Theatre, New Haven |music= Various |lyrics= Various |book= [[Woody Allen]]
[[Herbert Farjeon]]
[[Nina Warner Hook]] |basis= [[Revue]] |productions= 1960 [[Broadway theatre|Broadway]] |awards= }} '''''From A to Z''''' is a [[musical theatre|musical]] [[revue]] with a book by [[Woody Allen]], Herbert Farjeon, and Nina Warner Hook and songs by [[Jerry Herman]], [[Fred Ebb]], [[Mary Rodgers]], [[Everett Sloane]], Jay Thompson, Dickson Hughes, Jack Holmes, Paul Klein, Norman Martin, William Dyer, and [[Charles Zwar]]. ==Background== [[Hermione Gingold]] was asked to appear in a revue on Broadway by millionaires (and producers) Carroll Masterson and Harris Masterson and she asked her friend, [[Christopher Hewett]] to direct. Hewitt in turn recruited some of the cast and crew from Tamiment (an entertainment camp run in the summer), including the young [[Jonathan Tunick]], then a [[Juilliard]] student, as co-orchestrator with Jay Brower.Suskin, Steven. [https://books.google.com/books?id=Mwnv7tXZq1sC&dq=%22From+A+to+Z%22+%22Woody+Allen%22&q=%22From+A+to+Z%22#v=snippet&q=%22From%20A%20to%20Z%22&f=false " 'From A to Z' "] ''The Sound of Broadway Music: A Book of Orchestrators and Orchestrations'' (2009)(books.google.com), Oxford University Press, {{ISBN|0199831076}}, p.393 ==Production== The revue had its out-of-town tryout at the [[Shubert Theatre (New Haven)|Shubert Theatre]], [[New Haven]], Connecticut starting on March 26. ''From A to Z'' opened on [[Broadway theatre|Broadway]] at the [[Plymouth Theatre]] on April 20, 1960 and closed on May 7, 1960 after 21 performances. Directed by Christopher Hewett and choreographed by Ray Harrison, the cast included Hermione Gingold, [[Stuart Damon]], [[Bob Dishy]], [[Larry Hovis]], [[Virginia Vestoff]], Alvin Epstein and [[Paula Stewart]].Atkinson, Brooks. "Hermione Gingold Seen in Revue at Plymouth", ''The New York Times'', April 21, 1960, p. 23 Although a critical and commercial failure, the show is notable in that it marked the Broadway debuts of writer Allen, lyricist Ebb, composer Herman, ("Also making their mainstream debuts: Fred Ebb and Woody Allen.")Suskin, Steven. [https://books.google.com/books?id=_3mOZv6OaUIC&pg=PA314&dq=%22From+A+to+Z%22+%22Jerry+Herman%22&hl=en#v=onepage&q=%22From%20A%20to%20Z%22%20%22Jerry%20Herman%22&f=false "Chapter. Jerry Herman"] ''Show Tunes:The Songs, Shows and Careers of Broadway's Major Composers'' (4 ed. 2010), Oxford University Press, {{ISBN|978-0-19-531407-6}}, p.314and performer Virginia Vestoff. ==Plot overview== In one sketch, Gingold and Epstein played two wealthy hypocondriacs who compare their X-rays."The Openings", " 'From A to Z' Photo Caption", ''The New York Times'', April 17, 1960, p.X1 ==Songs== ;Act 1 *Best Gold - music and lyrics by Jerry Herman *Pill Parade - music and lyrics by Jay Thompson *Togetherness - music and lyrics by Dickson Hughes and Everett Sloane *Balloons - music and lyrics by Jack Holmes *Hire a Guy - music by Mary Rodgers, lyrics by Marshall Barer *Interlude - music and lyrics by Jack Holmes *I Said to Love - music by Paul Klein, lyrics by Fred Ebb *Charlie - music and lyrics by Fred Ebb and Norman Martin *The Sound of Schmaltz - music by William Dyer, lyrics by Don Parks ;Act 2 *Grand Jury Jump - music by Paul Klein, lyrics by Fred Ebb *South American Way - music by Norman Martin, lyrics by Norman Martin and Fred Ebb *Time Step - music by Paul Klein, lyrics by Fred Ebb *Red Shoes - music by Jack Holmes *Four for the Road - music by Paul Klein, lyrics by Lee Goldsmith and Fred Ebb *What Next? - music by Charles Zwar, lyrics by Alan Melville ==Reception== [[Brooks Atkinson]] in his ''[[The New York Times]]'' review noted that "There is no official writer; there is no house composer. Perhaps this is the reason the revue represents no point of view... Gingold is a comic of vast self-assurance who has very little variety." Atkinson praised the scenery and costumes ("Mr. Voelpel's costumes are also superb") and the performances of Alvin Epstein and Paula Stewart. In its review roundup, ''The New York Times'' reported that "Only John McClain of the ''[[New York Journal-American|Journal-American]]'' gave hearty support to this new revue starring Hermione Gingold."Funke, Lewis. "News and Gossip of the Rialto", "Round-Up", ''The New York Times'', April 24, 1960, p.X1 The ''[[Billboard (magazine)|Billboard]]'' reviewer noted that Gingold "displayed much keen sense of comedy; but one bright artist cannot make the production .... the scenes were not very titillating .... Musically, the individual songs were not distinctive." Ackerman, Paul. [https://books.google.com/books?id=wh8EAAAAMBAJ&dq=%22Hermione+Gingold%22+%22From+A+to+Z%22&q=%22Hermione+Gingold%22#v=snippet&q=%22Hermione%20Gingold%22&f=false " 'A to Z' Runs Mediocre Gamut"] ''Billboard Magazine'', (books.google.com), ISSN 0006-2510, April 25, 1960, p.21 ==References== {{reflist}} ==External links== * {{ibdb show|id=3736|title=From A to Z}} {{Mary Rodgers}} {{Jerry Herman}} {{Woody Allen}} [[Category:1960 musicals]] [[Category:Broadway musicals]] [[Category:Revues]] [[Category:Plays by Woody Allen]]

{{Unreferenced|date=December 2009}} [[Image:Haze machine.jpg|thumb|right|A haze machine with remote control]] '''Haze machines''', or haze generators (commonly referred to as hazers), are effects machines similar to [[fog machine]]s, designed to produce an unobtrusive, [[Homogeneous (chemistry)|homogeneous]] clouds suspended in the air intended primarily to make [[light beam]]s visible or create a subtle diffusion.
==Properties== [[File:Haze Mimi.jpg|right|thumb|Haze can reveal beams of light from [[stage lighting instrument]]s without obscuring the view of actors onstage.]] Unlike [[Theatrical smoke and fog|theatrical fog]], which is typically intended to be dense and/or opaque, haze is generally very light and subtle. These properties allow a venue to be filled with haze prior to or during an event without creating an overtly distracting cloud. Haze typically has a substantially longer persistence ("hang time") than conventional theatrical fog. While conventional fog will hang in the air for several minutes, a haze effect filling the same volume of space can last upwards of an hour to several hours or more, depending on the size of the venue and the amount of [[ventilation (architecture)|ventilation]].
The fluid used in haze machines to generate the effects are either oil or water-based. Most oil-based haze fluids use a [[mineral oil]] base, while water-based fluids use either a [[propylene glycol]] or [[glycerol]] base. Although both formulations of fluid are referred to as haze fluid, the different formulations are neither compatible nor interchangeable. Propylene glycol/water haze fluid is sometimes referred to as "water based haze" to avoid ambiguity. Describing the fluid as "glycol" might cause stagehands to use automotive antifreeze, which contains ethylene glycol,<ref>http://www.sciencelab.com/msds.php?msdsId=9927167</ref> and unlike propylene glycol, must not be used for this purpose because of its [[toxicity]].
==Technology==
===Crackers=== Crackers (also known as "oil crackers") were first developed in the 1960 and the fluid is usually, though not always, refined mineral oil. Crackers work by use of a spray pump powered either by electricity or compressed [[CO2|CO<sub>2</sub>]] passing through a dispersion head into a fluid reservoir. The compressed air [[aerosol]]s the fluid, dispersing fine droplets. Because the haze is mechanically generated, this type of machine does not require any warm up time.
===Pump spray=== Pump spray haze machines use electricity or compressed CO<sub>2</sub> to power a spray pump connected to a mixing valve, which draws in and atomizes the fluid.
Pump hazers also includes machines which function in the same manner as a [[fog machine]], pumping fluid into a heated chamber where it is [[vaporize|vapourized]] to produce a cloud. Hazers which heat fluid to create an atmospheric effect only use mixtures of water and glycol or glycerine. Spray hazers which atomize fluid can use either a water-based or mineral oil fluid.
===Aerosol=== Smaller volumes of haze can also be generated from aerosol canisters containing mineral oil under pressure. Although to the density of haze generated and the volume of space that can be filled is significantly smaller than that of a haze machine, aerosol canisters have the advantages of portability, no requirements for electricity and finer control over the volume of haze generated.
[[Image:Fog-laser.jpg|thumb|left| A laser passing through fog]]
===Ultrasonic=== Ultrasonic haze machines use [[transducer]]s submerged in a reservoir of fluid to create atmospheric effects. Although less common than some of the other technologies used to produce haze, ultrasonic hazers are promoted as generating their effects with much less noise than other technologies.
===Faze machines=== Faze machines, or fazers, can also be used to produce a haze-like effect. These machines are typically fog machines with a fan built in front to disperse the output, creating a haze-like effect. These machines are typically considered more cost effective, with prices ranging from $100–$400 USD as compared to haze machines with prices ranging from $400–$1,400 USD.
==Fire detection== Although the atmospheric effect created by hazers produces a significantly smaller particle size, around 1 micrometre, compared to the effect generated by a fog machine (hence the finer composition of the "cloud"), the size of particle and effect varies by manufactures and type of fluid used. Because of this haze is far less likely to set off fire alarms than fog machines or larger smoke particles.
==See also== *[[Theatrical smoke and fog]] *[[Fog machine]]
==References== {{Reflist}} *Entertainment Services & Technology Association (2005). ''Introduction to Modern Atmospheric Effects, 4th Edition.'', The ESTA Foundation. *Learn Stage Lighting (2013). "Hazers - Oil or Water Based?", [http://www.learnstagelighting.com/hazers-oil-or-water-based/ LearnStageLighting.com Oil Or Water Based]

{{Infobox comic book title |title = Jim |image = Jimv2no2woodring.jpg |imagesize = 100 |caption = ''Jim'', Vol. II No. 2 |publisher = [[Fantagraphics Books]] |startmo = Sept |startyr = 1987 |endmo = May |endyr = 1996 |issues = 4 (Vol. I)
6 (Vol. II) |creator = [[Jim Woodring]] |sort = Jim (comics) |US = y }} '''''Jim''''' is a [[comic book]] series by [[Jim Woodring]]. It began in 1980{{citation needed|date=April 2011}} as a self-published [[zine]] and was picked up by [[Fantagraphics Books]] in 1986 after cartoonist [[Gil Kane]] introduced Woodring to Fantagraphics co-owner [[Gary Groth]]. The publisher released four magazine-sized black-and-white issues starting in September 1987. A comic book-sized continuation, ''Jim Volume II'', with some color, began in 1993 and ran for six issues until 1996. ''Jim'', which Woodring described as an "autojournal", contained comics on a variety of subjects, many based on dreams, as well as [[surrealism|surreal]] drawings and free-form text which resembled Jimantha [[automatic writing]]. Besides dreams, the work drew on Woodring's childhood experiences, [[hallucination]]s, past [[alcoholism]], and [[Hinduism|Hindu]] beliefs. It also included stories of recurring Woodring characters such as Pulque (the embodiment of [[drunkenness]]), boyhood friends Chip and Monk, and, in ''Volume II'', his signature creation [[Frank (comics)|Frank]]. ==Content== ''Jim'' is made up of a variety of short comics, text pieces, and artwork. Most of the works are short comics based on Woodring's dreams. Some of the pieces are surreal parodies of advertisements in the ''[[Mad (magazine)|Mad]]'' tradition.{{sfn|Constant|2014}} ==Publication== The series began as a photocopied 12-page [[minicomic]] that Woodring self-published in 1980. The contents were drawn from Woodring's autojournal—a journal in which he recorded his dreams in comics, prose, drawings, and paintings.{{sfn|Van Winkle|2014}} [[Fantagraphics Books]] co-owner [[Gary Groth]] began publishing the series;{{sfn|Constant|2014}} the four issues of the first volume ran from 1987 to 1990.{{sfn|Spurgeon|2013}} Most of the contents of the first volume were reprinted in the book collection ''The Book of Jim'' in 1993.{{sfn|Spurgeon|2013}} A collection of both volumes appeared in 2014 under the title ''Jim'', subtitled ''Jim Woodring's Notorious Autojournal''.{{sfn|Constant|2014}} ===Vol. I=== #(Sep. 1987) #(Jan. 1988) #(Jan. 1989) #(Oct. 1990) ===Vol. II=== #(Dec. 1993) #*''Manhog Beyond the Face'' (color) #*''Quarry Story'' #(April 1994) #*untitled ''Frank'' story (color) #*untitled #*untitled ''Pulque'' story (color) #*untitled ''Big Red'' story #(July 1994) #*untitled #*''Authorized Only'' (digital color) #*''The Reform of the Apple'' #(Dec. 1994, printed Nov. 1994) #*''Frank and the Toy without Pity'' #*untitled ''Frank'' story (color) #*''Frank in the Cave of his Ancestors'' #(May 1995) #*''Dive Deep'' #*''Peeker'' (color) #*''The Stairs'' #*''Frank and the Sugar of Vengeance'' #*''Echo'' (inside back cover) #(May 1996, printed April 1996) #*''Obviously Not'' #*untitled ''Chip and Monk'' story #*''Boyfriend of the Weather'' ==Reception== Comics critic Joe McCulloch stated, "What Woodring did better than anyone was promote the idea that the subconscious, the imaginary, and the dreamtime state were perfectly valid terrains for autobiographical exploration" at a time when the confessional work of [[Justin Green (cartoonist)|Justin Green]] and the mundane stories of [[Harvey Pekar]] defined the range of [[autobiographical comics]].{{sfn|Spurgeon|2013}} ''Jim'' ranked No. 71 on ''[[The Comics Journal]]''{{'}}s list of the hundred greatest English-language comics of the 20th century.{{sfn|Spurgeon|2013}} ==Notes== {{Reflist}} ==References== {{Refbegin}} * {{cite web |last = Constant |first = Paul |title = A Stranger Genius of Literature, Back When He Used Words |date = September 3, 2014 |work = [[The Stranger (newspaper)|The Stranger]] |url = http://www.thestranger.com/seattle/a-stranger-genius-of-literature-back-when-he-used-words/Content?oid=20487063 |accessdate = January 18, 2015 |ref = harv}} * {{cite web |last = Spurgeon |first = Tom |authorlink = Tom Spurgeon |title = Fantagraphics Announces Re-Packaging Of Woodring Classic |date = July 20, 2013 |work = The Comics Reporter |url = http://www.comicsreporter.com/index.php/fantagraphics_announces_re_publishing_of_woodring_catalog/ |accessdate = January 18, 2015 |ref = harv}} * {{citation |last = Van Winkle |first = Nick |title = Northwest Reads by the University Book Store: 'Jim: Jim Woodring’s Notorious Autojournal' by Jim Woodring |url = http://www.newsofmillcreek.com/content/northwest-reads-university-book-store-jim-jim-woodring%E2%80%99s-notorious-autojournal-jim |date = August 18, 2014 |accessdate = January 18, 2015 |ref = harv}} {{Refend}} ==External links== *{{comicbookdb|type=title|id=30307|title=Jim}} *{{gcdb|id=26317|title=Jim}} {{Portal bar|Comics}} {{Jim Woodring}} {{Fantagraphics comics}} {{DEFAULTSORT:Jim (Comics)}} {{Refimprove|date=November 2008}} {{italic title}} [[File:Comic mural Le jeune Albert, Yves Chaland, Bruxelles.jpg|{{largethumb}}|[[Yves Chaland]]: ''Le jeune Albert''
([[Brussels' Comic Book Route]])]] '''''Ligne claire''''' ([[French language|French]] for "clear line") is a style of [[drawing]] pioneered by [[Hergé]], the Belgian creator of ''[[The Adventures of Tintin]]''. It uses clear strong lines all of the same width and no [[hatching]], while contrast is downplayed as well. Cast shadows are often illuminate. Additionally, the style often features strong colours and a combination of cartoonish characters against a realistic background. All these elements together can result in giving comics drawn this way a flat aspect. The name was coined by [[Joost Swarte]] in 1977.Pleban, Dafna. [http://comicfoundry.com/?p=1526 "Investigating the Clear Line Style," ComicFoundry (Nov. 7, 2006).] Accessed Oct. 2, 2008. == History == Hergé started out drawing in a much looser, rougher style which was likely influenced by American [[comic strip]] artists of the late 1920s and 1930s, such as [[Gluyas Williams]]Heer, Jeet. "Barnaby and American Clear Line Cartooning." ''Barnaby Volume One'' by [[Crockett Johnson]]. Fantagraphics Books, 2013. and [[George McManus]]. However the precise lines which characterize most of his work, are firmly in place from early on (e.g.: the colored version of ''The Blue Lotus'' (released in 1946) is based on the original black and white newspaper version from 1934–35 and not redrawn).Fingeroth, Danny. ''The Rough Guide to Graphic Novels''. Rough Guides, 2008. {{ISBN|1843539934}} (p. 25). For Hergé, the style was not limited to the drawings but extended to the story: the plot must be straightforward.{{Citation needed|date=April 2009}} Much of the "Brussels school" started to use this style, notably [[Edgar Pierre Jacobs|Edgar P. Jacobs]], [[Bob de Moor]], [[Roger Leloup]], and [[Jacques Martin (comics)|Jacques Martin]], many of whom also worked for ''[[Tintin (magazine)|Tintin]]'' magazine. The ''ligne claire'' style achieved its highest popularity in the 1950s, but its influence started to wane in the 1960s and was seen as old-fashioned by the new generation of comic book artists. In the late 1970s, it experienced a resurgence of interest, largely due to [[Netherlands|Dutch]] artists like [[Joost Swarte]] and [[Theo van den Boogaard]], who had come up through the Dutch underground comics scene, as well as the French artist [[Jacques Tardi]]. [[Henk Kuijpers]] was also successful in his application of the style. Throughout the 1980s, [[Yves Chaland]], [[Ted Benoit]], [[Serge Clerc]] and [[Floc'h]] relaunched the ''ligne claire'' style in France. This incarnation was a very stylistic and artistic variation, which the artists also utilized for illustrating posters and LP covers etc. Swarte dubbed this variant "atoomstijl" ("atomic style").[http://www.paulgravett.com/articles/article/in_search_of_the_atom_style1 In Search of the Atom Style] [[Paul Gravett]], 2009[http://www.atoomstijl.nl/index.html Atoomstijl.nl] Contemporary use of the ''ligne claire'' is often ironic or post-modern. For example, Van den Boogaard used the simple, clear style to set up a conflict with the amorality of his characters, while Tardi used it in his ''[[The Extraordinary Adventures of Adèle Blanc-Sec|Adèle Blanc-Sec]]'' series to create a nostalgic atmosphere which is then ruthlessly undercut by the story. A recent serious clear line artist is the [[Netherlands|Dutchman]] [[Peter van Dongen]], who created the ''[[Rampokan]]'' series about the [[Dutch East Indies|Dutch colonisation of Indonesia]]. ''Ligne claire'' is not confined to [[Franco-Belgian comics]]. British artists such as [[Martin Handford]], [[Bryan Talbot]] and [[Garen Ewing]]; Norwegian artists like [[Jason (comics)|Jason]]; American artists like [[Chris Ware]], [[Geof Darrow]], [[Jason Lutes]], and [[Jason Little (cartoonist)|Jason Little]]; Italian artists such as [[Vittorio Giardino]]: and Spanish artists such as [[Francesc Capdevila Gisbert]] ("[[:es:Max|Max]]") have also used it. == Notable ligne claire books/series == === Hergé === *''[[The Adventures of Tintin]]'' *''[[Jo, Zette and Jocko]]'' *''[[Quick and Flupke]]'' === Others === *''[[Jommeke]]'' — [[Jef Nys]] *''[[The Adventures of Freddy Lombard]]'' — [[Yves Chaland]] *''[[Alix]]'' — [[Jacques Martin (comics)|Jacques Martin]] * ''[[Barelli]]'' — [[Bob de Moor]] * ''[[Berlin (comics)|Berlin]]'' — [[Jason Lutes]] * ''Bingo Bongo et son Combo Congolais'' — [[Ted Benoît]] *''[[Blake and Mortimer]]'' — [[Edgar P. Jacobs]] *''[[César and Jessica]]'' *''[[Franka]]'' — [[Henk Kuijpers]] * ''Hector and Dexter'' (a.k.a. ''Coton et Piston'' and ''Katoen en Pinbal'') — [[Joost Swarte]] *''Julian Opie's Portraits'' — [[Julian Opie]] *''[[Kurt Dunder]]'' — [[Frank Madsen]] * ''[[Professor Palmboom]]'' — [[Dick Briel]] *''[[The Rainbow Orchid]]'' — [[Garen Ewing]] *''[[Jimmy Corrigan, the Smartest Kid on Earth]]'' — [[Chris Ware]] * ''[[Shutterbug Follies]]'' — [[Jason Little (cartoonist)|Jason Little]] *''[[Spike and Suzy]]'' (a.k.a. ''Bob and Bobette'', ''[[Willy and Wanda]]'', and ''Suske en Wiske'') — [[Willy Vandersteen]] * ''Tintin'' pastiches — [[Yves Rodier]] * ''[[Where's Wally?]]'' — [[Martin Handford]] *''[[Yoko Tsuno]]'' — [[Roger Leloup]] *''How to Understand Israel in 60 Days or Less'' — [[Sarah Glidden]] *''[[Sjef_van_Oekel#Comic_strip|Sjef van Oekel]]'' — [[Theo van den Boogaard]] ==See also== *[[Franco-Belgian comics]] *[[Marcinelle school]] – a contemporary, contrasting style == References == {{reflist|2}} ==External links== {{Commons category|Klare lijn}} *[http://klarelijninternational.midiblogs.com/ Klare lijn international] — News on ligne claire comics (in French) *[http://www.paulgravett.com/index.php/articles/article/herge_the_clear_line/ Hergé & The Clear Line: Part 1] {{Ligne claire}} {{Tintin and Hergé}} {{DEFAULTSORT:Ligne Claire}} [[Category:Comics terminology]] [[Category:Franco-Belgian comics]] [[Category:French words and phrases]] [[Category:Belgian comics]] [[Category:Hergé]]

A '''log profile,''' or '''[[Logarithmic scale|logarithmic]] profile,''' is a shooting profile, or [[Gamma correction|gamma curve]], found on some digital [[video camera]]s that gives a wide [[dynamic range|dynamic and tonal range]], allowing more latitude to apply colour and style choices. The resulting image appears washed out, requiring [[color grading]] in [[post-production]], but retains shadow and highlight detail that would otherwise be lost if a regular linear profile had been used that [[Clipping (photography)|clipped]] shadow and highlight detail. The feature is mostly used in [[filmmaking]] and [[videography]].
==Proprietary log profiles on various cameras== *C-Log or Canon Log on [[Canon Inc.|Canon]] cameras<ref>{{cite web|first1=Canon|last1=UK,www.canon.co.uk|accessdate=2018-10-07|title=Canon Log Gamma|url=https://www.canon.co.uk/cameras/eos-5d-mark-iv/canon-log-gamma/|website=www.canon.co.uk}}</ref> (including C-Log2 and C-Log3) *D-Log on [[DJI (company)|DJI]] UAV cameras<ref>{{cite news|accessdate=2018-10-07|title=How to shoot Log video using DJI's D-Log color profile|url=https://www.dpreview.com/articles/4978813437/how-to-shoot-log-video-using-dji-s-d-log-color-profile|newspaper=DPReview}}</ref> *F-Log on [[Fujifilm]] cameras<ref>{{cite web|accessdate=2018-10-07|title=LUT for F-Log (Look Up Table)|url=http://www.fujifilm.com/support/digital_cameras/software/lut/|website=www.fujifilm.com}}</ref> *N-Log on [[Nikon]] cameras<ref>{{cite web|accessdate=2018-10-07|title=Nikon introduces the new Nikon Z mount system, and releases two full-frame mirrorless cameras: the Nikon Z 7 and Nikon Z 6|url=https://www.nikon.com/news/2018/0823_mirrorless_01.htm|website=www.nikon.com}}</ref> *S-Log on [[Sony]] cameras<ref>{{cite web|accessdate=2018-10-07|title=S-Log|url=https://pro.sony/en_BE/technology/s-log|website=pro.sony}}</ref> (including S-Log2 and S-Log3)<ref>{{cite web|accessdate=2018-10-07|title=What is S-Log?|url=https://www.sony.co.uk/electronics/support/articles/00145908|website=www.sony.co.uk}}</ref>
==See also== *[[Raw image format]] *[[Rec. 709]]
==References== {{Reflist}}
