{{Use mdy dates|date=August 2016}} {{Infobox person | name = Morgan Strebler | image = MorganStrebler.jpg | caption = On location in Hollywood California during the filming of PopTV's Don't Blink. | residence = [[Las Vegas Valley|Las Vegas]], [[Nevada]] | birth_name = Matthew Glenn Milligan | birth_date = {{Birth date and age|1976|04|10|mf=y}} | birth_place = [[Sikeston, Missouri|Sikeston]], Missouri, US | occupation = [[Illusionist]], [[Magic (Illusion)|magician]] | spouse = Julie Russell 1999–present | children = 2 | website = [http://www.morganstrebler.com MorganStrebler.com] | height = 6'1" }}
'''Morgan Strebler''' (born '''Matthew Glenn Milligan''', April 10, 1976 in [[Sikeston]], [[Missouri]]) is an American psychological illusionist, actor, director, writer and producer. Strebler started practicing magic at the age of seven after seeing a live [[Harry Blackstone Jr]] performance. As an adult, Strebler started his acting career and moved to [[Las Vegas Valley|Las Vegas]] where he started construction on his multimillion-dollar illusion show.<ref>Street Magic Magazine Article. Issuu.com (November 12, 2010). Retrieved on 2012-02-25.</ref> Some of his earliest acting roles inculcated [[Sesame Street]] and at 17 he was on the [[The Young and the Restless|Young and the Restless]] and [[Guiding Light]].<ref>Imdb.me/morganstrebler</ref>
== Biography == Morgan's entree into the World of Illusion began as a child when his parents gave him a magic set for his birthday. Instantly bitten by the "magic bug", Morgan began performing for family and friends.
By his early teens, he was a local celebrity, performing close-up and stage magic for birthday parties, corporate events and church functions. Before achieving success, Strebler worked odd jobs ranging from a magician pitchman at Houdini's magic shop to working security at nightclubs in Las Vegas.
Strebler developed a professional persona around his signature "Liquid Metal"<ref>[http://www.penguinmagic.com/magician/morgan-strebler]. Penguinmagic.com Morgan Strebler Product Page (2015-16-09). Retrieved on 2012-02-25.</ref> routine in order to distinguish himself from other magicians. In 2003, he was asked to perform at [[Neverland Ranch]] for [[Joe Jackson (manager)|Joe Jackson]]'s birthday party.<ref>[http://www.lasvegassun.com/news/2006/mar/26/tom-gorman-visits-with-hard-working-magic-man-morg/ Tom Gorman visits with hard-working magic man Morgan Strebler, who continues his quest to make it to the top of the illusionists' world, the bright lights of the Las Vegas Strip – Sunday, March 26, 2006 | 7:01 am]. Las Vegas Sun. Retrieved on 2012-02-25.</ref> Later, he performed two nights a week at V bar inside [[The Venetian, Las Vegas|The Venetian]] and then five nights a week at the [[Bellagio (hotel and casino)|Bellagio Hotel and Casino]] inside the Caramel lounge. His regular performances later led to a comedy show at the [[Hard Rock Hotel and Casino (Las Vegas)|Hard Rock Hotel and Casino]] called Beachers Madhouse.<ref>[http://www.lasvegassun.com/news/2006/mar/26/tom-gorman-visits-with-hard-working-magic-man-morg Tom Gorman visits with hard-working magic man Morgan Strebler, who continues his quest to make it to the top of the illusionists' world, the bright lights of the Las Vegas Strip – Sunday, March 26, 2006 | 7:01 am]. Las Vegas Sun. Retrieved on 2012-02-25.</ref>
== Morgan Strebler Day == On March 7, 2016 The Mayor of Sikeston, MO ,Read a proclamation observing it as Morgan Strebler day.<ref>Standard Democrat march 24th,2016 ed., Morgan Strebler Day, page nine, Missouri Standard Democrat March 24, 2016.pdf</ref>
== Morgan Strebler vs Criss Angel == On January 8, 2007, Strebler issued a press release publicly challenging [[Criss Angel]] to "Live Close up, Live Stage Illusions", to be judged by a live audience, and to an endurance contest of [[Chinese water torture]]. Angel did not respond to the challenge and several months later a cover article in '''Street Magic Magazine''' described Strebler as "the man Criss Angel fears".<ref>[http://issuu.com/morganstrebler/docs/street_magic_article_with_morgan Street Magic Magazine Article]. Issuu.com (November 12, 2010). Retrieved on 2012-02-25.</ref> In 2011, Strebler publicly apologized to Angel on the Itricks podcast resulting in Angel and Strebler reconciling.
== The Man Who Bends Steel == [[Warner Brothers]]/[[DC Comics]] has given Morgan Strebler approval on January 5, 2014 to officially use "The Man Who Bends Steel" as his name/tag line. Just to clarify, so there absolutely no confusion. Morgan is not affiliated with Warner Brothers or DC Comics in any way, or their brand. He also not affiliated with any of their characters.<ref>http://www.supermansupersite.com/1213544.html</ref>
== Filmography == {| class="wikitable sortable" |- ! Year ! Title ! Role |- |1984 |Sesame Street (TV series) |Kid |Episode: 16.2 |- |1993 |The Young and the Restless (TV series) |Brad |episodes 1.5052 |- |1994 |Guiding light (TV series) |Mark |episode April 13, 1994 |- |1998 |Urban Legend | College Student (uncredited) |- |2000 |Nash Bridges (TV series) |Pool Guy |episode "jackpot" pt1 |- |2001 |The Mexican |Security Guard (uncredited) |- |2002 |Law and Order:Criminal Intent (TV series) |Homeless Guy |episode The Third Horseman |- |2012 |The Walking Dead (TV series) |Walker |episode When the Dead Come Knocking |- |2014 |Masters of Illusions (TV series) |Himself |episodes Evil Met His Match, Blindfold |- |2015 |Don't Blink (TV series) |Himself |episodes Mind Games and Blister Burns(2015) Glass Mutation, Erasing Time, and Pasta Surprise (2015) Metamorphoses, Mind Melds, and Motion Suspension (2015), London Calling, Burnt Offerings, and Deadly Levitations (2015) |- |2016 |Between Life and Death (TV Movie) | Psychic Entertainer / Mentalist |(post-production) |}<ref>[http://imdb.me/morganstrebler]. Imdb.com (2015-16-09).</ref>
{| class="wikitable sortable" |- ! Year ! Title ! Role |- |2016 |Between Life and Death (TV series) | Director, writer, Executive Producer |}<ref>[http://imdb.me/morganstrebler]. Imdb.com (2015-16-09).</ref>
== 36th Annual Superman Celebration == Morgan Strebler was invited as special guest in 2014 to the Superman Celebration in Metropolis, IL, and was asked to perform multiple shows on the main stage. From the Official press release on 5-7-14<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.supermansupersite.com/0507655.html |title=May 7, 2014: Superman Celebration to Host Super Line-Up of Entertainment |publisher=The Superman Super Site |date= |accessdate=2014-05-09}}</ref> Taking the stage and amazing the crowds with illusions will be Morgan Strebler, The Man Who Bends Steel. Strebler is a Bootheel Missouri native who calls Las Vegas home. Beginning in his early teens, Strebler has perfected the art of PsychoKinetic magic and is considered one of the world's leading experts and performers in this field. He became the youngest magician in the world to catch a live bullet between his teeth. Strebler has performed at Caesar's Palace, the Bellagio and the Venetian and has traveled internationally performing to more than a million people. He has entertained Hollywood stars and celebrities and has been on TV in 75 countries and performed on five continents. Strebler will take the stage on Friday at noon and 3:00 pm, Saturday at 10:00 a.m. and 5:00 pm, and Sunday at noon. You can find Strebler during the celebration on the streets entertaining crowds with close up illusions and magic.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.supermancelebration.net |title=The Official Site – Superman Celebration: The Official Site |publisher=Superman Celebration |date= |accessdate=2014-05-09}}</ref> During The Superman Celebration Morgan was given "The Superman of Metropolis award" It was signed by the Mayor of Metropolis and the head of the Chamber of Commerce.
== IMS Award == In March 2011, Strebler was honored for his metal bending skill with a [[Merlin Award]].<ref>[http://magicims.com/ma2010p/2011_yearbook.php 2011 Yearbook]. Magicims.com (May 11, 2011). Retrieved on 2012-02-25.</ref> In August 2013, Strebler received his second Merlin Award for "Cabaret Magician of the Year". As of October 7, 2015 Morgan has received word that he has won the 2015 Merlin Award for Mentalist of the Year.<ref>Magicims.com (2011-05-11)</ref>
==Published Author== In fall of 2014 Morgan released a hardback book Ice Cold alongside Ulises Galeano, and an Ebook Taste Conditions. Ice Cold can be found in major bookstores such as Barnes & Noble, [[Amazon Bookstore Cooperative|Amazon Books]] and many other fine bookstores. Taste Conditions is now available on the [[Barnes & Noble Nook|Nook]], Kindle, and iBooks.
==Publications== "The Opener", "The Closer", "Liquid Metal", "Liquid Metal 2", "Spun", "Taste Conditions", "Molten", "Sticky", "Failsafe", "Shadow", "Razor's Edge", "Ice Cold" "Pulse Stop" "Ice Cold DVD Set" "Popsicle sticks" "Toched DVD" "Konnected" "Flatline" "Never There"<ref>[http://www.penguinmagic.com/magician/morgan-strebler]. Penguinmagic.com Morgan Strebler Product Page (2015-16-09). Retrieved on 2012-02-25.</ref>
==Private life== Morgan is the only child to Brenda and Glenn Milligan. Born and raised in Sikeston, MO.
In 1995, Morgan met and fell in love with Julie, his high school sweetheart. They married in 1999 in Las Vegas, NV. Morgan and Julie have two children, Caleb(1996) and Hunter (2006). They currently reside in Las Vegas, NV.
==Liquid Metal Productions== In 2011, Strebler formed his own management company, Liquid Metal Productions, booking other magicians' shows around the world. Its roster includes RedStar Cartel, Paul Vigil, Cedric Taylor, and William Draven. Liquid Metal Productions sister company, Record Label (RMG), RedStar Music Group launched in 2012. RMG's first artist signed was rap group RedStar Cartel.

{{Use mdy dates|date=October 2011}} The '''National Parks Project''' is a Canadian music and film project. Released in 2011 to mark the 100th anniversary of the creation of the [[National Parks of Canada]] system,<ref name=dixon>[https://www.theglobeandmail.com/news/arts/movies/the-national-parks-project-wildlife-and-wild-music/article2028806/ "The National Parks Project: Wildlife and wild music"]. ''[[The Globe and Mail]]'', May 20, 2011.</ref> the project sent three Canadian musicians and a filmmaker to each of 13 Canadian national parks, one in each province and territory, to create and score a short documentary film about the park.<ref name=dixon />
The project was commissioned by [[Parks Canada]] and produced by FilmCAN and [[Primitive Entertainment]], in association with [[Discovery World HD]]. In addition to airing on Discovery World and on the web, the series was also screened at a number of film festivals, including Toronto's [[Hot Docs Canadian International Documentary Festival|Hot Docs]].
==Awards== [[Zacharias Kunuk]]'s segment, ''Sirmilik'', won the [[Genie Award]] for [[Academy of Canadian Cinema and Television Award for Best Documentary Short Film|Best Short Documentary Film]] at the [[32nd Genie Awards]].

{{about|the type of live show|the comedy series|Open Mike with Mike Bullard|type of gaffe|microphone gaffe}} {{pp-move-indef|small=yes}} {{Refimprove|date=April 2008}} [[Image:Little Grill open mic 2.jpg|thumb|right|150px|A poet reads her work at the [[Little Grill Collective|Little Grill]] open mic in [[Harrisonburg, Virginia]].]]
An '''open mic''' or '''open mike''' (derived from the expression "open microphone") is a live show at a [[coffeehouse]], [[nightclub]], [[comedy club]], [[strip club]], [[institution]] or [[pub]] at which audience members who are amateur performers or professionals who want to try out new material or plug an upcoming show are given the opportunity to perform onstage. Typically, as the name suggests, the performer is provided with a [[microphone]] which is plugged into a [[PA system]], to make the individual's performance loud enough for the audience to hear. Often the performers sign up in advance for a time slot with the host or [[master of ceremonies]], typically an experienced performer or the venue manager or owner. The master of ceremonies may screen potential candidates for suitability for the venue and give individuals a time to perform in the show. These events are focused on performance arts like [[poetry]] and [[spoken word]], music (often [[singer-songwriter]]s who [[accompaniment|accompany]] themselves on guitar), and [[comedy]]. Less commonly, small groups, such as a small [[rock band]] duo/trio or a comedy duo may appear. Group performances are uncommon, because of the space and the logistics of loading in and [[soundcheck]]ing such a group. In strip club terms, '''amateur night''' is a contest for everyday women and men who compete for a cash prize by [[Striptease|taking their clothes off]] just like everyday [[strippers]].
Open mic nights may have no [[cover charge]], or a very low cover charge, although the venue may have a [[gratuity jar]] or "pass the hat" for donations. Venues that have no charge make revenue from selling [[alcoholic beverage]]s and food. The performers are not typically paid, although the venue may recompense the performers with a beverage or meal. The host or MC, as an experienced professional, is usually paid for her/his services. The host or MC may perform at some point during the evening, either a full set or to fill in when an amateur member is not available for her/his slot. Open mic events are somewhat related to [[jam session]]s, in that in both cases amateur performers are given the opportunity to sing or play instruments. The difference is that jam sessions often involve musical ensembles, possibly even a [[house band]] or [[rhythm section]] and a jam session may involve the participation of professional performers, especially at a high-end [[jazz club]].
==Poetry and spoken word== Poetry and spoken word open mics feature a host, who is normally a [[poet]] or spoken word artist, poets and spoken word artists, and audience members. A sign-up is done before the show begins, so that the host has a list of names to call from. Some spoken word artists use [[pseudonym]]s or [[stage name]]s when they perform. Poetry/spoken word open mics range from laid back, serene settings to lively sessions where readers and/or performers compete for audience applause. They are usually held in libraries, [[coffee house]]s, cafes, bookstores and bars.
Each poet or spoken word artist is often asked to keep their performances to a minimum/specified time slot, giving each performer enough time to share some of their work with the audience. The host or MC acts as a "gatekeeper", determining which performers are suitable for the event. If a performer goes over their time limit, the host diplomatically thanks the performer for their contribution and asks them to yield the stage for the next performer.
==Comedy== Comedy open mic nights can be held at established [[comedy club]]s, but are more commonly held at other venues with or without a stage, often the upstairs or back room of a pub or bar. Such nights give newer or emerging comedians an opportunity to practice and improve, with a view to getting paid work in the future. More experienced comedians may use open mics as an opportunity to work out newer material or a new character, as the audience is not paying in anticipation of seeing their normal act. In a typical open mic night, newer acts will get three or maybe five minutes of stage time, but more experienced acts may get ten or more minutes.<ref>{{cite web |url=https://www.pdxcomedyblog.com/openmics |title=PDX Comedy Blog |website=PDX Comedy Blog |access-date=18 February 2018}}</ref>
There are booked shows, regular open mics and "bringer" shows. A booked show is usually booked week in advance with some lottery spots selected by pulling candidates' names from a hat. With a regular open mic, a person puts their name on the list and they go on when their name is called by the host. With a "bringer" show, each performer has to bring a certain number of people (friends, family members, etc.) to get on stage. Open mic shows may have no cover charge, a reduced cover charge, or a minimum drink requirement. Open mic comedy nights are most widespread in larger English-speaking cities with a well-established stand-up comedy scene, especially [[London]] and [[New York City|New York]]. In these cities, with a plethora of aspiring comedians, the greatest challenge may be in attracting an audience.{{Citation needed|date=July 2011}}
==Music== [[Image:Open Mic No Name Bar Sausalito CA July 2008.jpg|left|140px|thumb|A musician performs open mic at No Name Bar in [[Sausalito, California]].]] These shows provide an opportunity for emerging musicians to gain experience performing to a live audience without having to go through the process of getting normal music gigs, which is very difficult to do without experience or a demo recording.{{Citation needed|date=July 2011}} Open mics provide an outlet for [[singer-songwriter]]s. Prior to their popularity, the only outlet generally were [[folk clubs]], which were not always friendly towards creators of new music, preferring traditional, well-known music. They also suggested that music performed by [[acoustic music]]ians or solo artists in this manner would necessarily be folk music, a misconception that still commonly exists today. Some organizers have chosen the title "acoustic night" or "acoustic club" in an attempt to indicate an event run broadly on the lines of a folk club, but with a much wider range of musical styles.{{Citation needed|date=May 2015}}
Open mic events are most commonly held in the middle of the week or at the very end of the weekend when footfall through venues is low. They rarely occur on the hallowed Friday and Saturday night time slots when venues are busy with weekend revellers and any live performance is usually specifically booked, professional artists. The most common night for a [[UK]] open mic event is Thursday, followed by Wednesday.<ref>{{cite web|title=Open Mic Finder Statistics|url=http://openmicfinder.co.uk/Statistics|work=Open Mic Finder Statistics|accessdate=23 February 2013}}</ref>
In the [[United Kingdom]], the largest ongoing open mic-styled music contest is [[Open Mic UK]], which regularly attracts 10,000 participants of all genres. The grand prize for the contest is an investment up to £30,000. The size of the event has necessitated that all participants sign up for performance slots beforehand, instead of simply walking onstage.<ref name="tenwinners">{{cite news |url=http://www.openmicuk.co.uk/national_vote |title=2010 Winners |publisher=[[Open Mic UK]] |accessdate=2011-05-12}}</ref><ref name="birdy">{{cite news |url=http://www.bbc.co.uk/hampshire/content/articles/2008/12/06/birdy_ukidol_feature.shtml |title=Twleve year-old 'Birdy' wins UK talent contest |last=Almroth-Wright |first=Indy |date=December 6, 2008 |publisher=''[[BBC]]'' ([[Hampshire]]) |accessdate=2011-04-15}}</ref> [[File:Open_mic_blues_night.jpg|thumb|250px|right|Open mic blue jam, 2015]] A popular open mic arrangement in the United States is the "Blues Night". In this format a bar or club will dedicate a particular night, usually in the middle of the week, as being "open mic blues night". The establishment may supply a [[house band]], typically guitar, bass and drums, sometimes a [[keyboard instrument|keyboard]]. Singers, guitarists, harmonica performers who wish to play sign up, usually with the master-of-ceremonies or host. This person is tasked with screening the performers, choosing and ordering, and getting the performers on and off stage in a polite manner.
Since the songs chosen need to be simple enough so that a band of musicians who have not played together can perform them without practice, blues standards are used. Songs might be announced as a "12-bar fast shuffle in C" or "slow 12-bar blues in F", or similar phrases, that should be familiar to all concerned. Lead singers, keyboards, horn players, (usually saxophones) and various percussion instruments are common additions.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.rayrayblues.com/bluesjams/|title=Phoenix Blues Jams|first=|last=rayray|website=www.rayrayblues.com}}</ref>
==Strip club== In most strip clubs, amateur night is a contest held by the clubs themselves where women and men compete for cash by stripping just like their stripper counterparts.<ref>[http://www.scorestampa.com/blog/2015/02/01/want-to-be-a-stripper]</ref><ref>[http://www.stripclubs-of-las-vegas.com/deja-vu-showgirls-strip-club-review.html]</ref>
==Rarer niche variations== The terms "open deck" (where ''deck'' refers to the kind of [[Phonograph|turntable]] used by a [[DJ]]) and "open reel" (where ''reel'' refers to a [[35 mm film]] reel) are used for more niche open mic events where keen amateurs can meet to exhibit and [[critique]] their skills/artform. A decrease in the cost of consumer video technology combined with the powerful editing capabilities of modern PCs has caused an increase in the popularity of DJing and amateur filmmaking, but these types of events are still very rare.
==See also== *[[Open Mic UK]] (music competition in the UK, 2008–) *[[The Raving Poets]] (open mic poetry with live musical backing 2000-2010)
==References== {{reflist}}
==External links== * Aldredge, Marcus. "[http://caliber.ucpress.net/doi/abs/10.1525/si.2006.29.1.109?journalCode=si Negotiating and Practicing Performance: An Ethnographic Study of a Musical Open Mic in Brooklyn, New York.]" * Aldredge, Marcus. 2013. ''Singer-Songwriters and Musical Open Mics''. Farnham, UK: Ashgate.

Frank Baum]]}} | starring = {{Plainlist| * [[James Franco]] * [[Michelle Williams (actress)|Michelle Williams]] * [[Rachel Weisz]] * [[Mila Kunis]] * [[Zach Braff]] * [[Bill Cobbs]] * [[Joey King]] * [[Tony Cox (actor)|Tony Cox]] }} | music = [[Danny Elfman]] | cinematography = [[Peter Deming]] | editing = [[Bob Murawski]] | production companies = {{Plainlist| * [[Walt Disney Pictures]] * [[Joe Roth|Roth Films]] * Curtis-Donen Productions }} | distributor = [[Walt Disney Studios Motion Pictures|Walt Disney Studios
Motion Pictures]] | released = {{Film date|2013|02|14|[[El Capitan Theatre]]|2013|03|08|United States}} | runtime = 130 minutes{{cite web | url=http://bbfc.co.uk/releases/oz-great-and-powerful-film | title=''OZ THE GREAT AND POWERFUL'' (PG) | work=[[British Board of Film Classification]] | date=February 15, 2013 | accessdate=October 10, 2015}} | country = United States | language = English | budget = $200 million (gross){{Cite news|url=https://www.filmla.com/wp-content/uploads/2017/08/2013-Feature-Production-Report-w-Release-030614_1394125127.pdf|title=2013 Feature Film Study |last=FilmL.A. |date=March 1, 2014|accessdate=August 14, 2018}} $160 million (net){{Cite news|url=https://www.filmla.com/wp-content/uploads/2017/08/2013-Feature-Production-Report-w-Release-030614_1394125127.pdf|title=2013 Feature Film Study |last=FilmL.A. |date=March 1, 2014|accessdate=August 14, 2018}} | gross = $493.3 million{{cite web|url=http://www.boxofficemojo.com/movies/?id=oz.htm |title=Oz The Great and Powerful (2013) | publisher=[[Box Office Mojo]] |date=August 28, 2013}} }} '''''Oz the Great and Powerful''''' is a 2013 American [[fantasy film]] directed by [[Sam Raimi]] and written by [[David Lindsay-Abaire]] and Mitchell Kapner. Based on [[L. Frank Baum]]'s [[List of Oz books|''Oz'' novels]] and set 20 years before the events of the [[The Wonderful Wizard of Oz|original novel]],{{cite news|last=Schaefer|first=Sandy|title=No Dorothy in 'Oz the Great and Powerful' Sequel; WB Developing New 'Oz' TV Series|url=http://screenrant.com/oz-great-powerful-sequel-dorothy-wizard-oz-tv-show/|accessdate=April 10, 2014|newspaper=Screen Rant, LLC|date=March 12, 2013}} the film is a [[Spiritual successor|spiritual prequel]] to the 1939 [[Metro-Goldwyn-Mayer]] film ''[[The Wizard of Oz (1939 film)|The Wizard of Oz]]''.{{cite news|last=Barnes|first=Brookes|title=One More Trip to Land of Oz|url=https://www.nytimes.com/2013/03/04/business/media/disney-gambles-on-box-office-wizardry-of-oz.html?pagewanted=all&_r=0|accessdate=March 5, 2013|newspaper=The New York Times|date=March 3, 2013}} Starring [[James Franco]], [[Michelle Williams (actress)|Michelle Williams]], [[Rachel Weisz]], [[Mila Kunis]], [[Zach Braff]], [[Bill Cobbs]], [[Joey King]] and [[Tony Cox (actor)|Tony Cox]], the film tells the story of [[Wizard of Oz (character)|Oscar Diggs]], a deceptive magician who arrives in the [[Land of Oz]] and encounters three witches: [[Wicked Witch of the West|Theodora]], [[Wicked Witch of the East|Evanora]] and [[Glinda the Good Witch|Glinda]]. Oscar is then enlisted to restore order in Oz while struggling to resolve conflicts with the witches and himself. Kapner began developing an origin story for the [[Wizard of Oz (character)|Wizard of Oz]] after a lifelong interest of wanting to create one for the character. [[Walt Disney Pictures]] then commissioned the film's production in 2009 with [[Joe Roth]] as producer and [[Grant Curtis]], [[Joshua Donen]], Philip Steuer and Palak Patel serving as executive producers. Raimi was hired to direct the following year. After [[Robert Downey Jr.]] and [[Johnny Depp]] declined the titular role, Franco was cast in February 2011 with [[principal photography]] commencing five months later. [[Danny Elfman]] composed the film's score. ''Oz the Great and Powerful'' premiered at the [[El Capitan Theatre]] on February 14, 2013 followed by a general theatrical release on March 8, 2013 in [[Disney Digital 3-D]], [[RealD 3D]] and [[IMAX|IMAX 3D]] formats. Despite receiving mixed reviews from critics, the film grossed over $493 million worldwide against a $200 million budget, making it the 13th-highest-grossing [[2013 in film|film of 2013]]. The film won the Phoenix Film Critics Society Award for Best Live Action Family Film{{cite web| url =http://www.wmcactionnews5.com/story/24239588/phoenix-film-critics-release-winners-of-2013-awards| title=Phoenix Film Critics release winners of 2013 awards| work = Actionnews5.com | date= December 1, 2013|accessdate = February 26, 2017}} and Kunis won the 2014 [[MTV Movie Award for Best Villain]] for her performance as the [[Wicked Witch of the West]].{{cite web|first=Kimberly|last=Nordyke| url =http://www.hollywoodreporter.com/news/mtv-movie-awards-winners-2014-695760| title=MTV Movie Awards Winners: The Complete List| work=The Hollywood Reporter| date= April 13, 2014|accessdate = December 10, 2016}} ==Plot== In 1905 [[Kansas]], [[Wizard of Oz (character)|Oscar Diggs]] is a [[Magician (illusion)|magician]] and [[Confidence trick|con artist]] working for a [[Circus|traveling circus]]. As a storm approaches, the circus [[Strongman (strength athlete)|strongman]] learns that Oscar has flirted with his wife and threatens him. Oscar promptly escapes in a [[hot air balloon]], but is sucked into a [[tornado]] that takes him to the [[Land of Oz]]. There he encounters the beautiful and naïve witch Theodora, who believes him to be the wizard prophesied to become King of Oz by destroying the Wicked Witch who killed the previous king. The idea of being a wealthy monarch makes Oscar accept the role. En route to the [[Emerald City]], Theodora falls in love with Oscar though he does not reciprocate her feelings. They then encounter the flying monkey Finley who pledges a life debt to Oscar when he saves him from a [[Cowardly Lion|lion]]. Oscar reveals his deception to Finley and forces him to maintain the lie that he is really a wizard. At the Emerald City Theodora's beautiful older sister Evanora tells Oscar that the Wicked Witch resides in the Dark Forest and can be killed by destroying her wand. On the way to the forest they are joined by China Girl, a living [[china doll]] whose village and family were destroyed by the Wicked Witch. The three reach the forest and discover the "Wicked Witch" is the late king's daughter [[Glinda the Good Witch]], and Evanora is the true Wicked Witch. Evanora sees this with her [[crystal ball]] and tricks Theodora into thinking Oscar is trying to court all three witches at once. She offers Theodora a magic apple "to remove her heartache" but it turns her into a [[Wicked Witch of the West|hideous green-skinned witch]]. Glinda brings Oscar's group to her domain to escape Evanora's army of [[Winkie Country|Winkies]] and flying [[baboon]]s. She confides in Oscar that she knows he is not a wizard but still believes he can help stop Evanora. He reluctantly takes charge of an "army" of [[Quadling]]s, Tinkers and [[Munchkin]]s. Theodora enters Glinda's domain and angrily reveals her new hideous appearance to Oscar before threatening to kill him and his allies with the Emerald City's well-prepared army. Oscar despairs at his chances of victory, but after telling China Girl about the exploits of his hero [[Thomas Edison]] he conceives a plan that relies on [[sleight of hand|trickery]]. Glinda and her subjects mount a fake attack on the Emerald City using a pulley-rig army of [[scarecrow]] puppets hidden by thick fog. The witches are tricked into sending their flying baboons through a [[Poppy (flower)|poppy]] field that puts them to sleep. However two baboons capture Glinda. Meanwhile, Oscar infiltrates the Emerald City with his allies but apparently abandons them in a hot air balloon loaded with gold, which Theodora destroys with a fireball. As the wicked sisters prepare to execute Glinda, Oscar appears, having faked his betrayal and death. Using a hidden [[Fog machine|smoke machine]] and [[Projector|image projector]], he presents a giant image of his face as his "true" form and a fireworks display to intimidate the Wicked Witches. Evanora fearfully hides in her castle while Theodora flees on her broom, unable to hurt the "invincible" wizard. Oscar offers to Theodora that she would be welcome to return if she overcomes her wickedness, but Theodora refuses and flies away to the West laughing maniacally, leaving Oscar saddened. China Girl frees Glinda who engages Evanora in a magical duel. Glinda destroys Evanora's emerald necklace revealing her to be an old hag. Evanora is carried away by two flying baboons as she vows revenge. Oscar, now ruler of Oz, uses his projector to sustain the belief that he is a powerful wizard. He presents gifts to his friends: Master Tinker, who helped build his machines, receives Oscar's [[Pocket knife|jackknife]] while Knuck, the grumpy Munchkin herald, receives a mask with a smiley face; the long-suffering Finley receives Oscar's friendship along with his top hat and China Girl accepts her friends as her new family. Finally, Oscar takes Glinda behind the curtains of his projector, thanks her for making him a better person, and they kiss. ==Cast== * [[James Franco]] as [[Wizard of Oz (character)|Oscar Diggs]], a philandering [[confidence trick|con artist]], a [[Magic (illusion)|stage magician]] and a [[Wiktionary:barnstorm|barnstormer]]{{cite journal |url= http://www.ew.com/ew/article/0,,20679762,00.html |last= Nashawaty |first= Chris |title= 'Oz the Great and Powerful' |journal= [[Entertainment Weekly]] |location= New York |publisher= Time Inc. |date= March 15, 2013 |page= 43 |accessdate= March 16, 2013 |issue= 1250}} who is part of a traveling circus in the [[Midwestern United States|Midwest]]. He is whisked in a hot air balloon by a tornado to the [[Land of Oz]], where he is believed to be a wizard destined to bring peace to the land, forcing him to overcome his dubious ethics to convince his peers he is the hero needed by the people of Oz. He eventually becomes what is known as the Wizard of Oz. * [[Michelle Williams (actress)|Michelle Williams]] as [[Glinda the Good Witch|Glinda]], the daughter of the late king. She rules and protects a peaceful kingdom in Oz inhabited by kind Quadlings, tinkers, and Munchkins. Oscar originally believed her to be the Wicked Witch responsible for terrorizing the land. She guides Oscar to achieve his destiny of defeating Evanora, becoming his love interest in the process. ** Michelle Williams also plays Annie, an old flame of Oscar's and the future mother of [[Dorothy Gale]].{{cite news|last=Covert|first=Colin|title='Oz the Great and Powerful' is big and beautiful|url=http://www.salisburypost.com/article/20130310/SP03/130319982/1011|accessdate=11 March 2013|newspaper=Salisbury Post|date=10 March 2013|quote=He makes a young, svelte, rather hot conjurer who has broken many a heart, including that of Dorothy Gale's mom-to-be (liquid-eyed Michelle Williams, resplendent in a blond wig).}} * [[Rachel Weisz]] as [[Wicked Witch of the East|Evanora]], the protector of the Emerald City. Being the [[Wicked Witch of the East]], she has a hideous form which she hides by wearing a necklace that gives her the appearance of a young woman. She deceives Oscar by framing Glinda for the King's murder and telling Oscar that Glinda is the Wicked Witch rather than herself. * [[Mila Kunis]] as [[Wicked Witch of the West|Theodora]], a naïve good witch who has the Land of Oz's best interests at heart. She believes that Oscar is the wizard prophesied to defeat the seemingly evil Glinda from the Dark Forest, developing an attraction to him in the process. Evanora gradually manipulates Theodora into thinking Oscar has betrayed her for Glinda, ushering her transformation into the [[Wicked Witch of the West]].{{cite news|last=Lutz|first=Ashley|title=1939's Wicked Witch Of The West Looks Much Sexier In Today's 'Oz' |url=http://www.businessinsider.com/wicked-witch-of-the-west-then-and-now-2013-3|accessdate=March 19, 2013|newspaper=Business Insider|date=March 7, 2013}} * [[Zach Braff]] as the voice of Finley, a winged monkey who pledges an irrevocable life debt to Oscar, believing him to be the prophesied wizard, for saving him from the [[Cowardly Lion]]. He quickly regrets his decision when Oscar reveals he is not a wizard, but nonetheless becomes his loyal ally. ** Braff also plays Frank, Oscar's long-suffering yet loyal assistant in Kansas. * [[Bill Cobbs]] as Master Tinker, the leader of the [[tinker]]s who are ruled by Glinda. He would later build the [[Tin Woodman]]. * [[Joey King]] as the voice of China Girl, a young, living [[china doll]] from [[Quadling Country|China Town]] where everything, including its inhabitants, is made of china. Her home is destroyed by Evanora, leaving her its only survivor when she is found by Oscar, with whom she forms a strong friendship after he uses glue to fix her legs. ** King also plays a young girl in a wheelchair volunteering in Oscar's magic show in Kansas. * [[Tony Cox (actor)|Tony Cox]] as Knuck, the quick-tempered [[herald]] and fanfare player of Emerald City who is allied with Glinda. [[Stephen R. Hart]] and [[Bruce Campbell]] play [[Winkie Country|Winkie]] guards at the Emerald City. [[Abigail Spencer]] plays May, Oscar's temporary magic assistant in Kansas and one of his several fleeting loves in the film. [[Tim Holmes (actor)|Tim Holmes]] plays the [[Strongman (strength athlete)|strongman]] who attacks Oscar for trying to court his wife (played by Toni Wynne), prompting Oscar to take the hot air balloon that sends him to the Land of Oz. Raimi, who often casts friends and actor-regulars in [[cameo roles]], cast his brother [[Ted Raimi|Ted]] as a small-town skeptic at Oscar's magic show who yells "I see a wire!", two of his former teachers—Jim Moll and Jim Bird—as Emerald City townspeople and the three actresses from his 1981 directorial debut ''[[The Evil Dead]]'' —[[Ellen Sandweiss]], [[Betsy Baker]] and Theresa Tilly— as Quadling townspeople.{{cite news | url = http://www.newsday.com/entertainment/movies/oz-the-great-and-powerful-review-no-magic-but-close-1.4761788 | authorlink = Frank Lovece | first = Frank | last = Lovece | title = Great and Powerful Sam Raimi Connections | publisher = Sidebar to Rafer Guzman review of ''Oz the Great and Powerful'' | work = [[Newsday]] | date = March 6, 2013 | accessdate = April 9, 2013}} ==Continuity== ''Oz the Great and Powerful'' features several artistic allusions, [[Homage (arts)|homage]]s and technical parallels to Baum's novels and the 1939 [[Metro-Goldwyn-Mayer]] film, ''[[The Wizard of Oz (1939 film)|The Wizard of Oz]]''. The film's opening sequence is presented in black and white. When Oscar is caught up in the tornado, the audio switches from monaural to stereo and eventually surround sound.{{cite news|last=Patterson|first=John|title='Oz the Great and Powerful': Sam Raimi's not in Kansas anymore|url=https://www.theguardian.com/film/2013/mar/09/oz-the-great-and-the-powerful-sam-raimi|accessdate=19 March 2013|newspaper=The Guardian|date=8 March 2013}} The film shifts to full color when Oscar arrives in Oz; additionally, the [[Aspect ratio (image)|aspect ratio]] gradually widens from [[Academy ratio|4:3 Academy ratio]] to [[Aspect ratio (image)|2.35:1 widescreen]].{{cite news|last=Taylor|first=Drew|title=Oz the Great and Powerful': 10 Differences Between the Prequel and 'Wizard of Oz|url=http://news.moviefone.com/2013/03/06/oz-the-great-and-powerful-differences-wizard-of-oz_n_2820326.html#slide=2189907|accessdate=March 7, 2013|newspaper=Moviefone|date=March 6, 2013}}{{cite news|last=Patterson|first=John|title='Oz the Great and Powerful': Sam Raimi's not in Kansas anymore|url=https://www.theguardian.com/film/2013/mar/09/oz-the-great-and-the-powerful-sam-raimi|accessdate=March 19, 2013|newspaper=The Guardian|date=March 8, 2013}} As in the 1939 film, Glinda travels in giant bubbles, and the Emerald City is actually emerald; in the novel, characters wear tinted glasses to make it appear so. However, during the battle preparations sequence Oz can be seen wearing emerald goggles. The iconic green look of the [[Wicked Witch of the West]] is closer to her look in the 1939 film, as the Witch is a short, one-eyed crone in the novel. The Wicked Witches are portrayed as sisters, an idea which originated in the 1939 film. Also from the 1939 film is that several actors who play Oz characters make cameos in the Kansas segments, such as Frank, Oscar's assistant whom he refers to as his "trained monkey" (Frank's "Oz" counterpart is the winged monkey Finley) and a young girl in a wheelchair who serves as the Kansas counterpart to China Girl (in Kansas, Oscar is unable to make the wheelchair-bound young girl walk, and gets a chance to do so when he repairs China Girl's broken legs). Annie, a woman wearing a [[gingham]] dress who inspires Oscar to be a good and great person, informs him that she has been [[Marriage proposal|proposed]] to by John Gale, presumably hinting at [[Dorothy Gale]]'s parental lineage (Annie's "Oz" counterpart, Glinda, also inspires Oscar to be a better person).{{cite news|last=Covert|first=Colin|title='Oz the Great and Powerful' is big and beautiful|url=http://www.salisburypost.com/article/20130310/SP03/130319982/1011|accessdate=March 11, 2013|newspaper=Salisbury Post|date=March 10, 2013|quote=He makes a young, svelte, rather hot conjurer who has broken many a heart, including that of Dorothy Gale's mom-to-be (liquid-eyed Michelle Williams, resplendent in a blond wig).}} Other referenced characters include the [[Scarecrow (Oz)|Scarecrow]], who is built by the townspeople as a scare tactic, and the [[Tin Woodman]], whose creator is the Master Tinker that can build "anything", and the lion that attacks Finley, a reference to the [[Cowardly Lion]].{{cite news|last=Allport|first=Lee|title=Oz the Great and Powerful: A Prequel at Its Best|url=http://www.huffingtonpost.com/lee-allport/oz-the-great-and-powerful_1_b_2811167.html|accessdate=March 10, 2013|date=March 8, 2013|quote=There are other interesting "that explains it" moments as well. We get up-close-and-personal with The Cowardly Lion and find out what spooked him into being afraid of his own shadow. We get to know the Tin Man's father and the creators of the Scarecrow and learn more about Munchkinland.}} Similarly, various other races of Oz are depicted besides the [[Munchkin Country|Munchkins]]; the [[Quadling Country|Quadlings]], the china doll inhabitants of [[Quadling Country|Dainty China Country]], and the [[Winkie Country|Winkies]] (who went unnamed in the 1939 film). Similarly, Glinda is referred to by her title in the novel (the Good Witch of the South), unlike the 1939 film, where her character's title is "Good Witch of the North" (due to her character being merged with the [[Good Witch of the North]]). Glinda is also the daughter of the late King of Oz, though in the novels, [[Princess Ozma|Ozma]] is the King's daughter. Theodora's tears leave streaks of scars on her face, reflecting her weakness to water in the original novel/film. Also, Oz is presented as a real place as it is in the novel, and not as a possible dream as the 1939 film implies.L. Frank Baum, ''The Annotated Wizard of Oz'', edited by [[Michael Patrick Hearn]], New York, Crown, 1976; p. 96. {{ISBN|0-517-50086-8}}. ==Production== ===Disney's history with ''Oz''=== After the success of ''[[Snow White and the Seven Dwarfs (1937 film)|Snow White and the Seven Dwarfs]]'' in 1937, [[Walt Disney]] planned to produce an animated film based on the first of L. Frank Baum's ''[[The Wonderful Wizard of Oz|Oz]]'' books. However, [[Roy O. Disney]], the chairman of [[The Walt Disney Company|Walt Disney Productions]], was informed by Baum's estate that they had sold the film rights to the first book to [[Samuel Goldwyn]], who re-sold it to [[Louis B. Mayer]] in 1938.{{cite AV media |people=[[Angela Lansbury]], narrator, produced by John Fricke and Aljean Harmetz |date=1990 |title=The Wonderful Wizard of Oz, the Making of a Movie Classic |trans-title= |medium=Television |language= |url= |access-date= |archive-url= |archive-date= |format= |time= |location= |publisher=[[CBS]] Television |id= |isbn= |oclc= |quote= |ref= }} The film was ironically approved due to the success of ''Snow White''.{{cite news|last1=Staskiewicz|first1=Keith|title=Hello, Yellow Brick Road|url=http://ew.com/article/2013/03/01/hello-yellow-brick-road/|accessdate=May 12, 2017|work=Entertainment Weekly|date=March 1, 2013}} The project was then developed by [[Metro-Goldwyn-Mayer]] (MGM) into [[The Wizard of Oz (1939 film)|the well-known musical adaptation]] which was released the following year. In 1954, when the film rights to Baum's remaining thirteen ''Oz'' books were made available, Walt Disney Productions acquired them{{cite news | first=Bill | last=Chambers | title=A Conversation: FFC Interviews Academy Award-winning editor Walter Murch | url = http://www.filmfreakcentral.net/ffc/2012/05/a-conversation-ffc-interviews-walter-murch.html | publisher =Film Freak Central | accessdate = January 13, 2010 | archivedate = February 18, 2013 | archiveurl = https://www.webcitation.org/6EXGYCKkE | deadurl = no}} for use in Walt Disney's television series ''[[Walt Disney anthology television series|Disneyland]]'' which led to the live-action film ''[[Rainbow Road to Oz]]'', which was abandoned and never completed.{{cite web | last = Hill | first = Jim | title = Disney's long, long journey to Oz | url = http://jimhillmedia.com/editor_in_chief1/b/jim_hill/archive/2006/11/03/6565.aspx | publisher = Jim Hill Media | accessdate = July 13, 2012 | archivedate= March 7, 2013 | deadurl = no | archiveurl = https://web.archive.org/web/20130307025232/http://jimhillmedia.com/editor_in_chief1/b/jim_hill/archive/2006/11/03/6565.aspx}} Disney's history with the ''Oz'' series continued with the 1985 film ''[[Return to Oz]]'', which performed poorly, both critically and commercially,{{cite web | url = https://movies.nytimes.com/movie/review?res=9F03EFD91039F932A15755C0A963948260 | title=Film: A New 'Oz' Gives Dorothy New Friends | work = [[The New York Times]] | date = June 21, 1985 | accessdate = January 14, 2012 | last=Maslin | first = Janet }}{{cite news|title= Disasters Outnumber Movie Hits|publisher= [[South Florida Sun-Sentinel]]|url= http://articles.sun-sentinel.com/1985-09-04/features/8502060585_1_ticket-million-box-office|accessdate=June 5, 2012}}{{cite news | first=Dave | last=Kehr | title=Return to Oz | url =http://www.chicagoreader.com/chicago/return-to-oz/Film?oid=1073337 | work = [[Chicago Reader]] | accessdate = January 13, 2010 | archiveurl = https://web.archive.org/web/20121011204033/http://www.chicagoreader.com/chicago/return-to-oz/Film?oid=1073337 | archivedate= October 11, 2012 | deadurl =no}} but has developed a [[cult following]] since its release by fans of the books who considered it a more faithful adaptation to the ''Oz'' books than the 1939 classic.{{cite book | last =Geraghty | first =Lincoln | title =American Hollywood | publisher = Intellect Books | year =2011 | id = | isbn =978-1-84150-415-5| page =187}}{{cite web|url =http://www.etonline.com/movies/131252_Return_to_Oz_Flashback_with_Fairuza_Balk/index.html?viewFull=true | title=Flashback Exclusive: A 'Return to Oz'|date = March 5, 2013 | accessdate = March 15, 2013 | work = ET Online}} After ''Return to Oz'', Disney lost the film rights to the ''Oz'' books and they were subsequently reverted to the [[public domain]].{{cite news|last1=Jr|first1=Mike Fleming|title=Sam Raimi Commits To Disney 'Oz' Take, While 'Rabbit Hole' Scribe Will Rewrite|url=http://deadline.com/2010/10/disneys-oz-pic-gets-sam-raimi-to-commit-rabbit-hole-scribe-to-rewrite-73026/|accessdate=September 22, 2013 |website=Deadline Hollywood |date=October 6, 2010}} ===Development=== Screenwriter Mitchell Kapner was intrigued by the prospect of exploring the origins of the [[Wizard of Oz (character)|Wizard of Oz]] character which he discussed in many meetings. After ''[[Wicked (musical)|Wicked]]'' came out, Kapner felt he missed his window of opportunity.{{cite news|last=Galloway|first=Stephen|title='Oz's' Journey: 3 Studio Chiefs, Multi-Ethnic Munchkins, James Franco Scores $7 Million|url=http://www.hollywoodreporter.com/news/oz-great-powerful-disneys-200-424526?page=show|accessdate=March 7, 2013|newspaper=The Hollywood Reporter|date=February 27, 2013}} In 2009, Kapner met with [[Joe Roth]], who turned down his current pitches, request any other ideas he had. The discussion turned to what Kapner was reading which he indicated he was reading the Oz series to his kids. Roth was interested as he only knew about the first book. Kapner went through the plot of the novels, when Roth stopped him on the sixth novel in the series, ''[[The Emerald City of Oz]]'', which had some of back story of the Wizard.{{cite news|last=Hill|first=Jim|title=Joe Roth Reflects on Oz The Great and Powerful, Looks Forward to Maleficent in 2014|url=http://www.huffingtonpost.com/jim-hill/joe-roth-reflects-on-oz-t_b_2806542.html|accessdate=March 5, 2013|newspaper=Huffington Post|date=March 4, 2013}} Producer [[Joe Roth]] became involved for nearly the same reason as Kapner, stating that "… during the years that I spent running Walt Disney Studios—I learned about how hard it was to find a fairy tale with a good strong male protagonist. You've got your [[Sleeping Beauty (1959 film)|Sleeping Beauties]], your [[Cinderella (1950 film)|Cinderellas]] and your [[Alice in Wonderland (1951 film)|Alices]]. But a fairy tale with a male protagonist is very hard to come by. But with the origin story of the Wizard of Oz, here was a fairy tale story with a natural male protagonist. Which is why I knew that this was an idea for a movie that was genuinely worth pursuing." Kapner and co-writer Palak Patel presented the idea to [[Sony Pictures Entertainment|Sony Pictures]] but were turned down. In 2009, the project was set up at [[Walt Disney Pictures]] when the studio's president of production, [[Sean Bailey]] commissioned ''Oz the Great and Powerful'' under the [[working title]] ''Brick'' during the tenure of then [[Walt Disney Studios (division)|Walt Disney Studios]] chairman [[Dick Cook]], who was succeeded by [[Rich Ross]] and later [[Alan Horn]], a succession in management that a major studio release is rare to survive. [[David Lindsay-Abaire]] was later hired to do a re-write. Roth initially sought out [[Robert Downey Jr.]] for the titular role of the Wizard in April 2010.{{cite web | url = http://latimesblogs.latimes.com/movies/2010/04/robert-downey-jr-wizard-of-oz.html | title = Robert Downey Jr. as the Wizard of Oz? | work = [[Los Angeles Times]] | date = April 20, 2010 | accessdate = July 15, 2011 | archiveurl = https://www.webcitation.org/6EXHdpHYr | archivedate = February 18, 2013 | deadurl =no}} By summer of that year, [[Sam Raimi]] was hired to direct the film from a shortlist that reportedly included directors [[Sam Mendes]] and [[Adam Shankman]]. In January 2011, Raimi met with Downey, but did not secure his casting. With Downey's disinterest acknowledged, [[Johnny Depp]] was then approached due to his previous collaboration with the studio in the [[Pirates of the Caribbean (film series)|''Pirates of the Caribbean'' franchise]] and ''[[Alice in Wonderland (2010 film)|Alice in Wonderland]]''.{{cite web |url=http://www.hollywoodreporter.com/blogs/heat-vision/robert-downey-jr-oz-johnny-73615 |title=Exclusive: Robert Downey Jr. Out of 'Oz,' Johnny Depp to Take Over? | work = [[The Hollywood Reporter]] | date = January 19, 2011 | first = Borys | last = Kit | accessdate = July 15, 2011 | archivedate = January 21, 2011 | archiveurl = https://web.archive.org/web/20110121031644/http://www.hollywoodreporter.com/blogs/heat-vision/robert-downey-jr-oz-johnny-73615 | deadurl = no }} Depp liked the role but declined involvement, citing his commitment to another Disney [[Tent-pole (entertainment)|tentpole film]], ''[[The Lone Ranger (2013 film)|The Lone Ranger]]''. The film was without a lead until February when [[James Franco]] entered final negotiations to star in the film (including a $7 million salary), five months before filming was scheduled to begin. Coincidentally, Franco and Raimi had previously worked together on the [[Spider-Man in film#Sam Raimi films|2002-07 ''Spider-Man'' trilogy]].{{cite web |url=http://www.deadline.com/2011/02/james-franco-closing-disney-deal-for-oz-the-great-and-powerful |title=James Franco Closing Disney Deal For 'Oz: The Great And Powerful' |website=[[Deadline Hollywood]] | first = Mike | last = Fleming | date = February 25, 2011 | accessdate = July 15, 2011 | archiveurl = https://www.webcitation.org/6EXIFNtdn | archivedate = February 18, 2013 | deadurl = no}} To prepare for the role, Franco received training with retired magician [[Lance Burton]]. Screenwriter Kapner adopted information about the Wizard from L. Frank Baum's novels to conceptualize an original story. Raimi made sure that the film would also "nod lovingly" to the 1939 film and inserted several references and homages to that film.{{cite news|last=Del Barco|first=Mandalit|title='Oz,' The Great And Often Imitated|url=https://www.npr.org/2013/03/08/173735806/oz-the-great-and-often-imitated|accessdate=March 10, 2013|publisher=NPR|date=March 8, 2013|quote="We're trying to nod lovingly in its direction and make our own original, fun, wacky, emotional story that lives on its own."}} Disney wanted to reduce the film's [[production budget]] to be approximately $200 million. Casting calls were put out for local actors in Michigan.{{cite web |url=http://detroit.cbslocal.com/2011/06/10/casting-call-for-disneys-oz-the-great-and-powerful | title = Casting Call For Disney's 'Oz: The Great & Powerful' | publisher = [[WWJ-TV]] | location = Detroit, [[Michigan]] |date=June 10, 2011 |accessdate=July 15, 2011 | archiveurl = https://www.webcitation.org/6EXIdLGGB | archivedate = February 18, 2013 | deadurl =no}} In June 2011, composer [[Danny Elfman]] was hired to score ''Oz the Great and Powerful'' despite Elfman and Raimi having had a falling-out over ''[[Spider-Man 2]]'' and Elfman declaring that they would never again work together.{{cite web | url = http://www.chud.com/4718/elfman-vs-raimi-round-ii/ | title = Elfman vs. Raimi: Round II | first= Devin | last = Faraci | first2= Daniel Robert | last2=Epstein | date= October 13, 2005 | publisher= Chud.com | accessdate = February 17, 2013 | archiveurl = https://www.webcitation.org/6EVleQIGk | archivedate = February 17, 2013 | deadurl = no}} ===Filming=== [[Principal photography]] for ''Oz the Great and Powerful'' began July 25, 2011, at [[Motown Motion Picture Studios|Raleigh Michigan Studios]] in [[Pontiac, Michigan]], employing 3D cameras. Raimi opted to use [[Practical effect|practical sets]] in conjunction with [[computer-generated imagery]] during filming.{{cite news | last = Zeitchik | first = Steven | title = 'Wizard of Oz' prequel will win over skeptics, star says | url = http://latimesblogs.latimes.com/movies/2011/07/wizard-of-oz-james-franco-zach-braff-mila-kunis-sam-raimi.html | accessdate = January 31, 2013 | newspaper=[[Los Angeles Times]] | date = July 27, 2011 | archivedate = February 18, 2013 | archiveurl = https://www.webcitation.org/6EXKHbqKW | deadurl =no}} Physical sets were constructed so the actors could have a visual reference, as opposed to using [[Chroma key|green screen technology]] for every scene. Chroma key compositing was only used for background pieces.{{cite web|last=Sciretta|first=Peter|title=35 Things We Learned on the Set of Sam Raimi's 'Oz: The Great And Powerful'|url=http://www.slashfilm.com/35-things-we-learned-on-the-set-of-sam-raimis-oz-the-great-and-powerful/ | publisher=/Film | accessdate=January 31, 2013 | date = January 31, 2013 | archivedate = February 18, 2013 | archiveurl = https://www.webcitation.org/6EXJC4qBN | deadurl = no}} [[Zach Braff]] and [[Joey King]] were on set, recording their dialogue simultaneously with the other actors whenever their CG characters were present in a scene. Puppetry was employed for a physical version of the China Girl to serve as a visual key-point for actors to manipulate.Sciretta, p. [http://www.slashfilm.com/35-things-we-learned-on-the-set-of-sam-raimis-oz-the-great-and-powerful/2/ 2]. [https://www.webcitation.org/6EXJqlcz1 Archived] from the original on February 18, 2013. Braff wore a blue [[motion capture]] suit to create Finley's movements and had a camera close to his face for the flying sequences to obtain facial movements. Art director [[Robert Stromberg]], who worked on ''[[Avatar (2009 film)|Avatar]]'' and ''[[Alice in Wonderland (2010 film)|Alice in Wonderland]]'', drew inspiration from the films of [[Frank Capra]] and [[James Wong Howe]] to achieve the [[Art Deco]] design he envisioned for the [[Emerald City]]. Stromberg contrasted the colorful tonal qualities of ''Oz'' with the restrained appearance of ''Alice'', affirming that although both films explore similar fantasy worlds, the overall atmosphere and landscape of each "are completely different."{{cite news|last=McIntyre|first=Gina|title='Oz: The Great and Powerful': Robert Stromberg on Raimi, Burton, Baum|url=http://herocomplex.latimes.com/movies/oz-the-great-and-powerful-robert-stromberg-on-raimi-burton-baum/#/0|accessdate=March 7, 2013|quote=If you really broke it down, they're completely different. The elements in those two movies are completely different.|newspaper=Los Angeles Times|date=March 1, 2013}} In 2011, Stromberg and his team visited the [[Walt Disney]] archives during the pre-production phase to reference production art from Disney's animated films such as ''[[Pinocchio (1940 film)|Pinocchio]]'', ''[[Bambi]]'', ''[[Fantasia (1940 film)|Fantasia]]'', ''[[Cinderella (1950 film)|Cinderella]]'', ''[[Sleeping Beauty (1959 film)|Sleeping Beauty]]'', ''[[Alice in Wonderland (1951 film)|Alice in Wonderland]]'' and ''[[Snow White and the Seven Dwarfs (1937 film)|Snow White and the Seven Dwarfs]]'', drawing from designs and textures in order to give certain settings in the film an affectionate nod to the Disney style.{{cite web|last=Ehrbar|first=Greg|title=Sights & Sounds at Disney Parks: An Artist's Journey from Disney Parks to Oz|url=http://disneyparks.disney.go.com/blog/2013/03/sights-sounds-at-disney-parks-an-artists-journey-from-disney-parks-to-oz/|publisher=Disney Parks Blog|accessdate=March 9, 2013}} Costume designer [[Gary Jones (costume designer)|Gary Jones]] focused on authenticity with his wardrobe designs: "We started by doing a lot of research and having ideas of the ways (costumes) should look in order to be (historically accurate) but as we went on, we really began creating a whole new world."{{cite news|last=Longsdorf|first=Amy|title=Gary Jones finds the right fit for stars of 'Oz'|url=http://www.pottsmerc.com/article/20130303/LIFE01/130309989/gary-jones-finds-the-right-fit-for-stars-of-oz-|accessdate=March 7, 2013|newspaper=The Mercury|date=March 3, 2013}} {{quote box|width=30%|align=right|quote=My first instinct was, there are such iconic images in the Wizard of Oz movie, it would be wrong for us to re-create the Yellow Brick Road or the Emerald City in a different way. We had to go 180 degrees in the other direction. We're just going to have to make our own Oz.|source=Sam Raimi on recreating the Land of Oz under legalities.}} Although the film is a spiritual prequel to the 1939 [[Metro-Goldwyn-Mayer]] film ''[[The Wizard of Oz (1939 film)|The Wizard of Oz]]'', it was not allowed legally to be considered as such. The filmmakers had to toe a fine line between calling the film to mind but not [[Copyright infringement|infringing]] upon it. To that end, Disney had a copyright expert on set to ensure no infringement occurred. The production team worked under the constraint of abiding by the stipulations set forth by [[Warner Bros.]], the legal owner of the rights to iconic elements of the 1939 film (via its [[Turner Entertainment]] sister company which purchased the MGM film library in 1986), including the [[ruby slippers]] worn by [[Judy Garland]]. Therefore, Disney was unable to use them nor any original character likenesses from the 1939 film.{{cite news|last=Zeitchik|first=Steven|title=No place like Oz? Disney bets audiences are ready to ireturn|url=http://www.latimes.com/entertainment/movies/moviesnow/la-ca-wizard-oz-20130303,0,2458314.story|accessdate=March 1, 2013|newspaper=Los Angeles Times|date=March 1, 2013}} This extended to the green of the Wicked Witch's skin for which Disney used what its legal department considered a sufficiently different shade dubbed "Theostein" (a portmanteau of "Theodora" and "[[Frankenstein]]").{{cite news|last=Barnes|first=Brooks|title=We Aren't in the Old Kansas, Toto|url=https://www.nytimes.com/2013/03/03/movies/oz-the-great-and-powerful-disneys-wizard-of-oz-prequel.html|accessdate=February 28, 2013|newspaper=The New York Times|date=February 28, 2013}} Additionally, the studio could not use the signature [[Melanocytic nevus|chin mole]] of [[Margaret Hamilton (actress)|Margaret Hamilton]]'s portrayal of the [[Wicked Witch of the West]] nor could they employ the [[yellow brick road]]'s swirl design for [[Munchkinland]]. The expert also ensured that the Emerald City was not too close in appearance to the original Emerald City in the 1939 film. While Warner and Disney did not engage in copyright battle, they did file rival trademarks. In October 2012, Disney filed a trademark on "Oz the Great and Powerful" while one week later Warner filed its own trademarks for "The Great and Powerful Oz." The [[United States Patent and Trademark Office|U.S. Patent and Trademark Office]] suspended Warner's attempt at a trademark because Disney had filed basically the same one a week earlier.{{Cite news|url=https://www.hollywoodreporter.com/thr-esq/wizard-of-oz-disney-warner-bros-289305|title=Disney, Warner Bros. Fighting Over 'Wizard of Oz' Trademarks (Exclusive)|last=Gardner|first=Eriq|date=February 13, 2012|work=The Hollywood Reporter|access-date=March 19, 2018|archive-url=|archive-date=|dead-url=}} In addition to the legal issues, the film was also faced with delays when several cast members went on hiatus due to unrelated commitments and circumstances. [[Rachel Weisz]] left halfway through the shoot to film her entire role in ''[[The Bourne Legacy (film)|The Bourne Legacy]]'', [[Michelle Williams (actress)|Michelle Williams]] was required to promote the release of ''[[My Week with Marilyn]]'' and Franco's father died during production. Roth compared the task of managing overlapping schedules to "being an air-traffic controller." [[Mila Kunis]]'s makeup and prosthetics were supervised by [[Greg Nicotero]] and demanded four hours to apply and another hour to remove, with Kunis taking nearly two months to fully recover from the subsequent removal of the makeup from her skin.{{cite news|last=McIntyre|first=Gina|title='Oz the Great and Powerful' and 'Walking Dead'? Nicotero is connection|url=http://herocomplex.latimes.com/movies/oz-the-great-and-powerful-and-walking-dead-nicotero-is-connection/|accessdate=28 July 2013|newspaper=The Los Angeles Times|date=11 March 2013}} Raimi had to edit the frightening nature of several scenes to secure Disney's desired PG rating from the [[Motion Picture Association of America|MPAA]]. [[Sony Pictures Imageworks]] was contracted to create the film's visual effects.{{cite web|title=Sony Pictures Imageworks Vancouver Studio Continues To Build Stable Of Talent With Addition Of Jason Dowdeswell, Steve Nichols|url=http://www.prnewswire.com/news-releases/sony-pictures-imageworks-vancouver-studio-continues-to-build-stable-of-talent-with-addition-of-jason-dowdeswell-steve-nichols-190074721.html|agency=PR Newswire|accessdate=March 7, 2013}} ===Music=== Composer [[Danny Elfman]] noted that the film's score was accessibly quick to produce, with a majority of the music being written in six weeks.{{cite news|last=McIntyre|first=Gina|title='Oz': Teaser, character posters hint at Sam Raimi's lavish vision|url=http://herocomplex.latimes.com/2013/01/29/oz-teaser-character-posters-hint-at-sam-raimis-lavish-vision/#/0|accessdate=January 31, 2013|newspaper=Los Angeles Times|date=January 29, 2013 | archivedate = February 18, 2013 | archiveurl = https://www.webcitation.org/6EXK8rfk5 | deadurl = no}} Regarding the tonal quality of the score, Elfman stated, "We're going to take an approach that's old school but not self-consciously old-fashioned. Let the melodrama be melodrama, let everything be what it is. I also think there's the advantage that I'm able to write narratively, and when I'm able to write narratively I can also move quicker because that's my natural instincts, I can tell a story in the music."{{cite news|last=McIntyre|first=Gina|title=Composing wizard Danny Elfman talks sweeping, gigantic 'Oz' score|url=http://herocomplex.latimes.com/2013/01/10/danny-elfman-oz-score/#/0|accessdate=January 31, 2013|newspaper=Los Angeles Times|date=January 10, 2013}} American singer-songwriter [[Mariah Carey]] recorded a promotional Pop single called "[[Almost Home (Mariah Carey song)|Almost Home]]" written by Carey, Simone Porter, Justin Gray, Lindsey Ray, Tor Erik Hermansen, and Mikkel Eriksen (a.k.a. [[Stargate (music producers)|Stargate]]) for the soundtrack of the film. The single was released on February 19, 2013 by [[Island Records]].{{cite press release | title = Updated Release: Global Superstar Mariah Carey Records 'Almost Home' For Disney's 'Oz The Great and Powerful' | url = https://www.reuters.com/article/2013/02/06/updated-disneys-oz-idUSnPnNY55543+160+PRN20130206 | publisher = [[Walt Disney Pictures]] via [[Reuters]] | date = February 6, 2013 | accessdate = February 18, 2013 | archiveurl = https://www.webcitation.org/6EXKaS3o9 | archivedate = February 18, 2013 | deadurl = no}} ====Soundtrack==== The original soundtrack to ''Oz the Great and Powerful|url=http://www.the-numbers.com/movie/Oz-The-Great-and-Powerful#tab=video-sales|accessdate=30 January 2015|newspaper=The Numbers|date=9 September 2013}} ==Reception== ===Box office=== ''Oz the Great and Powerful'' earned $234.9 million in the United States and Canada, and $258.4 million in other countries for a worldwide total of $493.3 million. Worldwide, it was the thirteenth-highest-grossing [[2013 in film|film of 2013]].{{cite web|url=http://www.boxofficemojo.com/yearly/chart/?view2=worldwide&yr=2013&p=.htm|title=2013 Yearly Box Office Results - Box Office Mojo|work=[[Box Office Mojo]]|publisher=[[IMDb]]|accessdate=June 9, 2014}} Calculating in all expenses, ''[[Deadline Hollywood]]'' estimated that the film made a profit of $36.4 million.{{cite web|url=http://deadline.com/2014/03/hunger-games-catching-fire-hobbit-desolation-of-smaug-profit-most-profitable-movies-2013-701686/|title=2013 Most Valuable Blockbuster – #5 'The Hunger Games: Catching Fire' Vs. #12 'World War Z'; #4 'Hobbit: The Desolation Of Smaug' Vs. #13 'Oz The Great And Powerful'|author=Mike Fleming Jr|website=[[Deadline Hollywood]]|date=March 21, 2014|accessdate=March 22, 2015}} It topped the box office on its worldwide opening weekend with $149 million.{{cite web|url=http://boxofficemojo.com/alltime/world/worldwideopenings.htm|title=All Time Worldwide Opening Records at the Box Office|accessdate=August 30, 2013|publisher=Box Office Mojo}} Before its theatrical release, several media outlets reported that ''Oz the Great and Powerful'' was expected to duplicate the box office performance of 2010's ''[[Alice in Wonderland (2010 film)|Alice in Wonderland]]''.{{cite news|last=Smith|first=Grady|title=Box office preview: Will 'Oz' be as 'Great and Powerful' as 'Alice in Wonderland'?|url=http://insidemovies.ew.com/2013/03/07/box-office-preview-oz-great-and-powerful/|accessdate=May 25, 2013|newspaper=Entertainment Weekly|date=March 7, 2013|quote=The fantasy film, which also opened in March, started with $116.1 million on opening weekend, but without the cachet of Johnny Depp and Tim Burton, it's unlikely that Oz will achieve such a gargantuan figure. }}{{cite news|last=Barnes|first=Brooks|url=https://www.nytimes.com/2013/03/04/business/media/disney-gambles-on-box-office-wizardry-of-oz.html?pagewanted=all&_r=1&|title=One More Trip to Land of Oz |accessdate=May 25, 2013|newspaper=The New York Times|date=March 3, 2013|quote=The company (Disney) is betting that a new twist on a story moviegoers already love will result in a hit on par with 'Alice in Wonderland,' which took in more than $1 billion in 2010.}}{{cite news|title="Oz the Great and Powerful" tops box office with $80M debut|url=http://www.cbsnews.com/8301-207_162-57573531/oz-the-great-and-powerful-tops-box-office-with-$80m-debut/|accessdate=May 25, 2013|publisher=CBS News|date=March 11, 2013|quote='Oz' could follow in the footsteps of Disney's 'Alice in Wonderland,' another costly 3-D film, which opened on the same weekend in 2010 and went on to gross over $1 billion worldwide.}} However, ''Oz'' accumulated less than half of ''Alice''{{'}}s worldwide gross.{{cite web|title=Alice' Vs. 'Oz|url=http://boxofficemojo.com/showdowns/chart/?id=aliceoz.htm|publisher=Internet Movie Database|accessdate=May 26, 2013}} Preliminary reports had the film tracking for an $80–$100 million debut in North America.{{cite news|last=McClintock|first=Pamela|title=Box Office Preview: 'Oz' Eyeing Great and Powerful Global Opening|url=http://www.hollywoodreporter.com/news/box-office-preview-oz-eying-426641|accessdate=March 7, 2013|newspaper=The Hollywood Reporter|date=March 7, 2013}} The movie earned $2 million from 9 p.m. showings on Thursday night.[http://www.hollywoodreporter.com/news/oz-great-powerful-earns-2-426875 Box Office Report: 'Oz' Grosses Stellar $2 Million in Thursday Night Shows]. Retrieved March 8, 2013 For its opening day, ''Oz the Great and Powerful'' grossed $24.1 million, the fourth-highest March opening day.[http://boxofficemojo.com/news/?id=3646&p=.htm Friday Report: 'Oz' Conjures $24.1 Million Debut]. Retrieved March 9, 2013 During its opening weekend, the film topped the box office with $79.1 million, the third-highest March opening weekend.[http://boxofficemojo.com/news/?id=3647&p=.htm Weekend Report: 'Oz' Has Magical Debut, 'Dead Man' Dies] Retrieved March 10, 2013 Despite the film's solid debut, which was larger than nearly all comparable titles, it clearly lagged behind [[Alice in Wonderland (2010 film)|''Alice in Wonderland'']]'s opening ($116.1 million). The film's 3-D share of the opening weekend was 53%. Females made up 52% of the audience. Surprisingly, though, families only represented 41% of attendance, while couples accounted for 43%. The film retained first place at the box office during its second weekend with $41.3 million.[http://boxofficemojo.com/news/?id=3652&p=.htm Weekend Report: 'Oz' Leads, 'Call' Exceeds, 'Burt' Bombs]. Retrieved March 18, 2013 Outside North America, the film earned $69.9 million on its opening weekend from 46 territories. Among all markets, its highest-grossing debuts were achieved in Russia and the [[Commonwealth of Independent States|CIS]] ($14.7 million), China ($9.06 million),{{cite web|url=http://www.boxoffice.com/china/2013-04-02-box-office-mr-right-rules-oz-posts-respectable-debut|title=BOX OFFICE: 'Mr. Right' Rules; 'Oz' Posts Respectable Debut|publisher=|accessdate=October 1, 2014}} France and the Maghreb region ($5.77 million).{{cite web|url=http://www.boxofficemojo.com/movies/?page=intl&id=oz.htm|title=Oz The Great and Powerful (2012) - International Box Office Results|publisher=|accessdate=October 1, 2014}} The film's openings trailed ''Alice in Wonderland'' in all major markets except Russia and the CIS.{{cite news|url=http://www.boxofficemojo.com/news/?id=3648&p=.htm|date=March 12, 2013|title=Around-the-World Roundup: 'Oz' Opens to $69.9 Million Overseas|first=Ray|last=Subers|accessdate=April 13, 2013}} It retained first place at the box office outside North America for a second weekend.{{cite news|url=http://www.boxofficemojo.com/news/?id=3653&p=.htm|date=March 19, 2013|title=Around-the-World Roundup: 'Oz' Rules Again, 'Die Hard' Scores in China|first=Ray|last=Subers|accessdate=April 13, 2013}} In total grosses, ''Oz''{{'}}s largest countries are Russia and the CIS ($27.4 million), China ($25.9 million) and the UK, Ireland and Malta ($23.4 million). ===Critical response=== On [[review aggregator]] [[Rotten Tomatoes]], ''Oz the Great and Powerful'' received an approval rating of 60% based on 253 reviews, with an average rating of 6/10. The site's critical consensus reads, "It suffers from some tonal inconsistency and a deflated sense of wonder, but ''Oz the Great and Powerful'' still packs enough visual dazzle and clever wit to be entertaining in its own right."{{cite web|url=http://www.rottentomatoes.com/m/oz_the_great_and_powerful/ |title= Oz the Great and Powerful (2013) |publisher= [[Rotten Tomatoes]] |date= January 5, 2017 |accessdate= March 5, 2013}} On [[Metacritic]] the film holds a score of 44 out of 100, based on 42 critics, indicating "mixed to average reviews".{{cite web|url=http://www.metacritic.com/movie/oz-the-great-and-powerful |title= Oz the Great and Powerful reviews|publisher= [[Metacritic]] |accessdate=March 5, 2013}} Audiences polled by [[CinemaScore]] gave the film an average grade of "B+" on an A+ to F scale.{{cite web |url=https://m.cinemascore.com |title=CinemaScore |work=cinemascore.com}} [[Kim Newman]], writing for ''[[Empire (film magazine)|Empire]]'', gave the film 4 out of 5 stars and said, "If there are post-[[Harry Potter]] children who don't know or care about ''The Wizard Of Oz'', they might be at sea with this story about a not-very-nice grownup in a magic land, but long-term Oz watchers will be enchanted and enthralled … Mila Kunis gets a gold star for excellence in bewitchery and Sam Raimi can settle securely behind the curtain as a mature master of illusion."{{cite web |url= http://www.empireonline.com/reviews/reviewcomplete.asp?FID=137178 |author= Newman, Kim |authorlink= Kim Newman |date= March 2013 |title= 'Oz The Great and Powerful' |work= [[Empire (film magazine)|Empire]] |accessdate= March 5, 2013}} Critic Alonso Duralde also admired the movie: "That ''Oz the Great and Powerful'' is so thoroughly effective both on its own terms and as a prequel to one of the most beloved movies ever made indicates that this team has magic to match any witch or wizard."{{cite web |url= http://www.thewrap.com/movies/column-post/oz-great-and-powerful-review-sam-raimi-manages-fill-some-mighty-big-ruby-slippers-80141|author= Duralde, Alonso |date= March 5, 2013 |title= ''Oz the Great and Powerful'' Review: Sam Raimi Manages to Fill Some Mighty Big Ruby Slippers |publisher= The Wrap |accessdate= March 5, 2013}} [[Leonard Maltin]] on ''[[IndieWire]]'' claimed that "No movie ever can, or will, replace 1939's ''The Wizard Of Oz'', but taken on its own terms, this eye-filling fantasy is an entertaining riff on how the Wizard of that immortal film found his way to Oz."{{cite web |url= http://blogs.indiewire.com/leonardmaltin/oz-the-great-and-powerful |author= Maltin, Leonard |authorlink= Leonard Maltin |date= March 2013 |title= 'Oz the Great and Powerful' |publisher= [[IndieWire]] |accessdate= March 8, 2013}} [[IGN]] rated the film 7.8 and said, "The film is expansive and larger-than-life in scope and so are the performances, overall. Franco in particular hams it up and is often playing to the balcony … The 3D is utilized just as it should be in a children's fantasy epic such as this – overtly, but with skill. Snowflakes, music boxes and mysterious animals all leap through the screen towards the audience as the story unfolds."{{cite web |url= http://www.ign.com/articles/2013/03/04/oz-the-great-and-powerful-review |author= Cornet, Roth |date= March 4, 2013 |title= Who is a Good Witch, What is a Great Wizard? |publisher= IGN |accessdate= March 5, 2013}} Justin Chang of ''[[Variety (magazine)|Variety]]'' had a mixed reaction, writing that the film "gets some mileage out of its game performances, luscious production design and the unfettered enthusiasm director Sam Raimi brings to a thin, simplistic origin story."{{cite news|last=Chang|first=Justin|title=Film Review: 'Oz the Great and Powerful'|url=https://variety.com/2013/film/reviews/film-review-oz-the-great-and-powerful-820799/|accessdate=March 6, 2013|newspaper=Variety|date=February 28, 2013}} He also compared the film's scale with the [[Star Wars|''Star Wars'' prequel trilogy]] adding, "In a real sense, ''Oz the Great and Powerful'' has a certain kinship with [[George Lucas]]'s ''Star Wars'' prequels, in the way it presents a beautiful but borderline-sterile digital update of a world that was richer, purer and a lot more fun in lower-tech form. Here, too, the actors often look artificially superimposed against their CG backdrops, though the intensity of the fakery generates its own visual fascination." [[/Film]] rated the film 7 out of 10, saying it had "many charms" while considering it to be "basically ''[[Army of Darkness]]'': (Normal guy lands in magical land, is forced to go on quest to save that land.) But just when you see Raimi's kinetic, signature style starting to unleash, the story forces the film back into its Disney shell to play to the masses. We're left with a film that's entertaining, a little scarier than you'd expect, but extremely inconsistent."{{cite web |url= http://www.slashfilm.com/oz-the-great-and-powerful-review-a-sam-raimi-movie-wrapped-inside-a-disney-movie/ |author= Lussier, Germain |date= March 5, 2013 |title= ''Oz the Great and Powerful'' Review: A Sam Raimi Movie Wrapped Inside a Disney Movie |publisher= [[/Film]] |accessdate= March 5, 2013}} [[Richard Roeper]], writing for [[Roger Ebert]], noted the film's omnipresent visual effects but was largely disappointed by the performance of some cast members; "… to see Williams so bland and sugary as Glinda, and Kunis so flat and ineffectual as the heartsick Theodora …"{{cite web|last=Roeper|first=Richard|title=Oz the Great and Powerful review - Wicked or wussy: Which witch is worse?|url=http://rogerebert.suntimes.com/apps/pbcs.dll/article?AID=/20130306/REVIEWS/130309990|work=Chicago Sun-Times|accessdate=March 7, 2013}} [[Marshall Fine]] of ''[[HuffPost|The Huffington Post]]'' was unimpressed, writing, "Oh, it's exciting enough for a six-year-old; anyone older, however, will already have been exposed to so much on TV, at the movies and on the Internet that this will seem like so much visual cotton-candy. Even a sophisticated grade-schooler will find these doings weak and overblown."{{cite web |author= Fine, Marshall |date= March 4, 2013 |title= Movie Review: ''Oz, the Great and Powerful'' |work= Huffington Post}} Similarly, [[Todd McCarthy]] criticized the characterization, writing that the film's supporting cast "can't begin to compare with their equivalents in the original … so the burden rests entirely upon Franco and Williams, whose dialogue exchanges are repetitive and feel tentative."{{cite news|last=McCarthy|first=Todd|title=Oz the Great and Powerful: Film Review|url=http://www.hollywoodreporter.com/movie/oz-great-powerful/review/425417|accessdate=March 6, 2013|newspaper=The Hollywood Reporter|date=February 28, 2013}} ''[[Entertainment Weekly]]'' agreed, giving the film a C+ and saying that the "miscast" Franco "lacks the humor, charm, and gee-whiz wonder we're meant to feel as he trades wisecracks with a flying monkey … and soars above a field of poppies in a giant soap bubble. If ''he'''s not enchanted, how are ''we'' supposed to be?" and complaining that "while Raimi's Oz is like retinal [[Crack cocaine|crack]], he never seduces our hearts and minds." Alisha Coelho of [[in.com]] gave the movie 2.5 stars, saying "''Oz The Great and Powerful'' doesn't leave a lasting impression, but is an a-ok watch."{{cite web|url=http://www.in.com/news/entertainment/movie-review-oz-the-great-powerful-is-aok-50192564-in-1.html| title=Movie Review: Oz the Great & Powerful is a-ok | author=Alisha Coelho | publisher=in.com| accessdate=March 5, 2013}}{{Rating|2.5|5}} ===Accolades=== {| class="wikitable" width="95%" |- style="background:#ccc; text-align:center;" ! colspan="5" style="background: LightSteelBlue;" | Awards |- style="background:#ccc; text-align:center;" ! A '''pasindhèn''' (informally '''sindhèn'''; also called '''waranggana''') is a female solo singer who sings with a [[gamelan]]. They may perform in unaccompanied music, dance, or [[wayang]] performances.
The pesindhèn may sing together with a [[gerong]] (male chorus), but their styles and words will be different. The part of the sindhen is largely improvised within strict parameters (similar to instrumental [[cengkok]]). The sindhen is also allowed a much freer rhythm, similar to the [[rebab]] and [[suling]], instead of the strict rhythm of the gerong.
'''Sindhen''' can also refer to the choir of male and female singers used to accompany the [[bedhaya]] and [[serimpi]] court dances. In this usage, ''pesindhen'' refers to the individual members of the choir.
==References== * [[Jaap Kunst|Kunst, Jaap]]. ''Music in Java''. The Hague: Martinus Nijhoff, 1949. Page 127. * Walton, Susan Pratt. ''Heavenly nymphs and earthly delights: Javanese female singers, their music and their lives''. PhD thesis. University of Michigan, 1996. * Walton, Susan Pratt. ''Mode in Javanese Music''. Monographs in International Studies: Southeast Asia Series 79. Athens: Ohio University Press, 1987.

'''Prison Performing Arts''' is a literacy and performing arts program aimed at adults and children incarcerated in Missouri jails and prisons.
Prison Performing Arts was featured on a dedicated episode of [[National Public Radio|NPR]]'s ''[[This American Life]]'' where they followed men incarcerated in prison in Pacific, Missouri as they performed Act V of [[Shakespeare]]'s ''[[Hamlet]]''.
==Sources== * [http://www.thisamericanlife.org/radio-archives/episode/218/Act-V Act V] ''[[This American Life]]'', [[Chicago Public Radio]], August 9, 2002.
